Evernote, the note-taking service, is facing a user backlash after restricting the number of features available to free accounts. The company's Evernote Basic tier, which offers free access to the software, will now only be able to sync across two devices. For most people, this will be a computer and one mobile device, leaving users with more than one computer, or a computer and two mobile devices (a phone and a tablet, for instance), needing to pay for the first time. Free users can still access the web version of Evernote, though. At the same time, the price for the Plus and Premium tiers of Evernote has risen by about 40%, taking them to $34.99 (£25.96) and $69.99 (£51.92) a year respectively. The move has sparked widespread criticism from users who feel that the new restrictions are a significant blow to the service's value proposition. Many users have taken to social media to express their disappointment and frustration, with some even threatening to switch to alternative note-taking apps.

"This is a huge step backwards for Evernote," said Sarah Johnson, a freelance writer who has been using the service for years. "I understand that the company needs to make money, but restricting the number of devices you can sync with is a major inconvenience. I'll be looking into alternative options for note-taking."

Evernote's decision to restrict the number of devices that can be synced with the free account has also raised questions about the company's commitment to providing a seamless user experience. Many users rely on the service to access their notes across multiple devices, and the new restrictions will require them to pay for a premium subscription to achieve this.

"It's frustrating to see a company like Evernote, which has built its reputation on providing a flexible and accessible service, suddenly impose such restrictive limits on its free users," said Tom Smith, a student who uses Evernote to take notes during lectures. "I'm not sure I'm willing to pay for a premium subscription just to access the features I need."

Despite the backlash, Evernote has defended its decision, citing the need to maintain the quality and reliability of its service. In a statement, the company said: "We're committed to providing the best possible experience for our users, and that means making sure that our service is reliable and secure. The changes we've made to our pricing and features are designed to help us achieve this goal, while also providing our users with more value and flexibility."

However, many users remain unconvinced, and the controversy is likely to have a significant impact on the company's reputation and user base. As the debate continues to rage on social media and online forums, it remains to be seen whether Evernote will be able to recover from the backlash and maintain its position as one of the leading note-taking services.

The ABC is reporting that its former managing director Michelle Guthrie has received a payout of more than $800,000 after being terminated by the public broadcaster, but is still suing for more. An ABC spokesperson said the termination payment was made to Guthrie in line with her contractual entitlements. Guardian Australia understands it was determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, which oversees federal public servants' pay. According to sources, Guthrie's termination payment is the result of a complex negotiation process between her legal team and the ABC's management. The payout is reportedly the largest ever made to a departing ABC executive, and has raised eyebrows among industry insiders and observers.

Guthrie's lawsuit, which is ongoing, alleges that her termination was unfair and unjustified. She claims that she was unfairly targeted by the ABC's board and management, and that her departure was motivated by a desire to eliminate her as a potential competitor for the role of managing director.

The ABC has denied these allegations, stating that Guthrie's termination was a result of a performance review that identified significant issues with her leadership style and management of the organization. The broadcaster has also accused Guthrie of breaching her contract by failing to comply with certain obligations and responsibilities.

The dispute between Guthrie and the ABC has sparked a heated debate about the role of the public broadcaster in Australian society, and the accountability of its executives. Some have called for greater transparency and oversight of the ABC's management practices, while others have defended the organization's autonomy and independence.

The Remuneration Tribunal's role in determining Guthrie's termination payment has also been criticized by some, who argue that the tribunal's decisions are often opaque and lack transparency. Others have defended the tribunal's process, saying that it is necessary to ensure fair and consistent treatment of federal public servants.

As the dispute continues to unfold, the Australian public is left to wonder what the future holds for the ABC and its leadership. Will the organization be able to move forward from this controversy, or will it continue to be plagued by internal strife and external criticism? Only time will tell.

The sucker punch has been coming ever since the press – with hundreds of local newspaper editors up front – tried to fend off the supposed royal charter regulatory menace of article 40 (the one where publishers pay legal costs, win or lose). Lord Justice Leveson's insistence on a regulator offering cheap arbitration was a terrible sticking point, the editors said: a final burden on a struggling industry. Which, of course, made arbitration itself the litmus test for MPs and ministers wondering what to do next. Thus the culture, media and sport committee now gives Ipso (the non-Leveson-compliant regulator almost everyone has joined) a year to implement an acceptable arbitration scheme. The move by the culture, media and sport committee to give Ipso a year to implement an acceptable arbitration scheme has been met with mixed reactions from the industry. While some have welcomed the extension, others have expressed frustration and disappointment at the lack of concrete action to address the long-standing issue.

Ipso, which was established in 2014 as a self-regulatory body for the UK press, has faced criticism for its failure to implement a robust arbitration system. The organization has argued that it has been working towards implementing a scheme, but has faced technical and logistical challenges.

However, critics have accused Ipso of dragging its feet and failing to provide a meaningful solution to the problem. "A year is a long time, and we need to see real progress on this issue," said Tom Watson, a Labour MP and member of the culture, media and sport committee. "The press needs to take responsibility for its own regulation, and that includes implementing a fair and effective arbitration system."

The issue of arbitration has been a major sticking point in the debate over press regulation. The Leveson Inquiry, which was established in 2011 to investigate phone hacking and other abuses by the press, recommended that a regulator be established with the power to impose arbitration on publishers. However, the press industry has long resisted this proposal, arguing that it would be a costly and burdensome requirement.

The culture, media and sport committee's decision to give Ipso a year to implement an arbitration scheme is seen as a compromise between the press industry's demands and the government's desire to see meaningful regulation in place. However, some have argued that it is a missed opportunity to take a more robust approach to regulation.

"The government has failed to grasp the nettle on press regulation," said Hacked Off, a campaign group that has been pushing for greater regulation of the press. "Instead of giving Ipso a year to implement a half-baked arbitration scheme, they should be introducing a robust and independent regulator with the power to hold the press to account."

The debate over press regulation is likely to continue in the coming months, with the culture, media and sport committee set to hold further hearings and the government expected to introduce legislation on the issue. Whatever the outcome, it is clear that the press industry will need to adapt to a changing regulatory landscape, and that arbitration will remain a key part of that debate.

My former colleague Norman Dewis, who has died aged 98, was for most of his working life the highly respected chief test driver for Jaguar, and was one of the last survivors from Jaguar's heyday of the 1950s and 60s. He was born in Coventry, the son of Florence (nee Wilday) and Cyril Dewis. His education was cut short when his father, a coal merchant and carter, died in 1934, and Norman had to find work. Norman Dewis's early years were marked by hardship and determination. He began working at the age of 14, taking on various jobs to support his mother and younger sister. His first employment was as a messenger boy for the local council, followed by stints as a milkman and a shop assistant.

However, Norman's passion for cars soon took over, and he began working at a local garage, where he honed his mechanical skills and developed a deep understanding of engines and mechanics. His talent and dedication did not go unnoticed, and in 1947, he was approached by Jaguar's chief test driver, William Heynes, who offered him a job as a junior test driver.

Dewis accepted the offer and quickly proved himself to be an exceptional driver and mechanic. He worked tirelessly alongside Heynes, testing and developing Jaguar's early models, including the iconic XK120 and XK140. His expertise and attention to detail earned him the respect of his colleagues and the admiration of his employers.

As Jaguar's chief test driver, Norman Dewis played a crucial role in the development of the company's most iconic models, including the E-Type and the XJ6. His testing and feedback were instrumental in refining the performance, handling, and reliability of these vehicles, which went on to become legendary in the world of motoring.

Dewis's legacy extends beyond his contributions to Jaguar's success. He was a mentor and inspiration to many young engineers and drivers, and his dedication to his craft earned him a reputation as one of the most respected and skilled test drivers in the industry.

Throughout his long and illustrious career, Norman Dewis remained humble and grounded, always crediting his colleagues and the company for his success. He was a true ambassador for Jaguar and a testament to the company's commitment to excellence.

In his later years, Dewis continued to be involved with Jaguar, attending classic car events and sharing his stories and experiences with enthusiasts. His passing leaves a void in the world of motoring, but his legacy will live on through the many lives he touched and the iconic cars he helped shape.

Among some astronomers, there is a growing suspicion that our solar system's distant reaches conceal a large, ninth planet that we have not yet seen. New findings about a small ice world far beyond Pluto buttress this idea. On Monday, astronomers led by Scott S. Sheppard of the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington revealed the orbital details of the world, which they have nicknamed the Goblin. The discovery of the Goblin, officially designated as 2015 TG387, has sparked renewed interest in the possibility of a large, undiscovered planet lurking in the outer reaches of the solar system. Sheppard and his team used the Subaru Telescope in Hawaii to observe the Goblin's orbit, which takes a whopping 40,000 years to complete around the sun.

The Goblin's unusual orbit is what caught the attention of astronomers, as it appears to be influenced by the gravitational pull of an unseen massive body. Sheppard and his team believe that this body could be the long-sought ninth planet, which they have dubbed Planet Nine.

"We've been searching for this missing planet for a long time, and now we have a real candidate," said Sheppard in a statement. "The Goblin's orbit is unlike anything we've seen before, and it's a strong indication that there's something massive out there that's affecting its path."

The Goblin itself is a small, icy world, measuring approximately 300 kilometers in diameter. It is one of the most distant known objects in the solar system, with an average distance from the sun of about 65 astronomical units (AU). One AU is the average distance between the Earth and the sun.

While the Goblin's discovery is exciting, it is not yet conclusive evidence of the existence of Planet Nine. However, the findings do provide strong supporting evidence for the theory. Sheppard and his team plan to continue observing the Goblin and other similar objects in the hopes of gathering more data that could confirm the presence of the elusive planet.

The search for Planet Nine has been ongoing for several years, with astronomers using a combination of observations and computer simulations to try and locate the missing world. The discovery of the Goblin has reignited interest in the search, and scientists are eager to see what other secrets the distant reaches of the solar system may hold.

As the search for Planet Nine continues, scientists are also exploring the implications of its potential existence. If confirmed, the planet could provide valuable insights into the formation and evolution of the solar system, as well as the possibility of life beyond Earth.

For now, the Goblin remains a mysterious and intriguing addition to our understanding of the solar system, and astronomers will continue to study it in the hopes of uncovering more secrets about the distant reaches of our cosmic neighborhood.

Price: £18,555 Top speed: 121mph 0-62mph: 9.4 seconds MPG: 45.6 CO2: 144g/km It's Italian, it's stunning and its name references the greatest love story ever written… But spend a week with Giulietta from Alfa Romeo and you'll soon be booking sessions with Relate. Like most relationships, it started so well. You spotted the car across a crowded car park and your eyes were drawn by those dramatic lines. The rimless headlamps and plunging codpiece grille added to the appeal. You took the key from your pocket, you wanted to get to know this car a little better. You pressed unlock and… eergh… the car emits a long, dreadful jarring beep. I've "beeped" a lot of cars in my time, but the tone on this one is awful. It sounds crazy to dismiss a car because the security tone is too harsh, too long and too unnecessary, but every time I locked or unlocked Giulietta that noise put my teeth right on edge. Clamber in and the disappointment continues. As I settled into the driver's seat, I was met with a sea of black plastic and a steering wheel that felt more like a chunk of granite than a tactile delight. The seats, while comfortable, lacked the plushness and support I've come to expect from Italian luxury brands. The dashboard, a mishmash of buttons and dials, seemed more suited to a budget-friendly supermini than a premium hatchback.

The infotainment system, while responsive, was slow to boot up and took an eternity to navigate. The graphics were dated, and the lack of Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration was a glaring omission. It was as if Alfa Romeo had taken a step back in time, forgetting the importance of modern connectivity in today's connected world.

But, I thought, perhaps the driving experience would make up for these shortcomings. After all, Alfa Romeo has a rich heritage of producing cars that are a joy to drive. I put the Giulietta into gear and set off, eager to see if it could redeem itself.

The initial impression was promising. The engine, a 1.4-liter turbocharged unit, provided a decent amount of punch, and the six-speed manual transmission was smooth and precise. The handling, while not as sharp as some of its rivals, was still engaging and fun.

However, as the miles ticked by, the Giulietta's flaws began to reveal themselves. The ride was firm, bordering on harsh, and the suspension struggled to absorb even the smallest of bumps. The steering, while accurate, lacked the feel and feedback that I've come to expect from a car in this class.

As the week drew to a close, I couldn't help but feel a sense of disappointment. The Giulietta, while not a bad car by any stretch, failed to live up to my expectations. The noise, the bland interior, and the lackluster driving experience all combined to make it a car that, despite its stunning looks, felt like a missed opportunity.

In a crowded and competitive market, the Giulietta needs to stand out from the crowd. Unfortunately, it falls short. With its flaws and shortcomings, it's a car that's hard to recommend, even to the most ardent Alfa Romeo fan. Perhaps, as the saying goes, "all's fair in love and war," but when it comes to cars, I think it's fair to say that this Giulietta is a love that's lost its spark.

Q. Is possible to bold or italicize text in Outlook for Android? ...in Outlook for Android?

Yes, it is possible to bold or italicize text in Outlook for Android. While Outlook's formatting options may not be as extensive as those found in desktop versions of the email client, you can still add emphasis to your messages using the app's built-in formatting tools.

To bold or italicize text in Outlook for Android, follow these steps:

1. Open the email composition window and type the text you want to format.
2. Tap the "Format" button located at the top of the screen, which looks like a paint roller.
3. From the format menu, select "Font" and then choose the desired font style from the options provided. You can choose from a range of font styles, including bold, italic, and underline.
4. Once you've selected the desired font style, the text will be formatted accordingly. You can also adjust the font size and color using the options available in the format menu.

It's worth noting that the formatting options available in Outlook for Android may vary depending on the device and version of the app you're using. However, the basic steps outlined above should work for most users.

In addition to bolding and italicizing text, Outlook for Android also allows you to add other formatting elements to your messages, such as headings, bullet points, and links. To access these features, simply tap the "Format" button and select the desired option from the menu.

Overall, while the formatting options in Outlook for Android may not be as extensive as those found in desktop versions of the email client, the app still provides a range of tools that can help you add emphasis and style to your messages.

Now is a good time to find the constellations based on the Greek myth of Perseus. The chart shows the core of these constellations: Perseus, Cassiopeia, Andromeda and Pegasus. They can be found high in the sky looking south this week. As the summer months approach, stargazers are in for a treat as the constellation of Perseus becomes more visible in the night sky. The mythological tale of Perseus, a demigod from ancient Greece, is brought to life as the stars align to form the shape of the constellation.

For those looking to spot the constellations, the key is to look southwards in the evening, around 9pm. The chart highlights the core of the constellations, with Perseus, Cassiopeia, Andromeda, and Pegasus all visible in the same region of the sky. The constellations are best viewed when the sky is clear and dark, allowing for the stars to shine through with minimal light pollution.

Perseus, the constellation, is said to represent the hero of the myth, who beheaded the snake-haired Medusa and saved Andromeda from the sea monster Cetus. The constellation is easily recognizable by its distinctive "W" shape, formed by the bright stars Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta Persei.

Cassiopeia, on the other hand, is named after the queen in the myth who boasted about her beauty, leading to the gods sending the sea monster Cetus to attack her daughter Andromeda. The constellation is shaped like a "W" or an "M", depending on the time of year and the observer's location.

Andromeda, the princess, is said to be chained to a rock as a sacrifice to the sea monster, but was saved by Perseus, who killed the beast and freed her. The constellation Andromeda is formed by the bright stars Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta Andromedae, and is easily recognizable by its distinctive "V" shape.

Pegasus, the winged horse, is said to have been born from the blood of the Gorgon Medusa, whom Perseus beheaded. The constellation is formed by a group of bright stars that resemble a square or a rectangle, with the bright star Alpha Pegasi marking the "nose" of the horse.

For those interested in stargazing, now is an excellent time to get out and spot these constellations. With the summer months approaching, the nights are getting longer and darker, making it easier to see the stars. Grab a pair of binoculars, find a dark spot away from city lights, and get ready to be transported to the world of ancient Greek mythology.

Years before Facebook, Instagram and Twitter took over as the prime spots for oversharing, people had to go to websites like Open Diary, Blogger and LiveJournal to publish their thoughts for the world to read. But over time, social media became the way that people shared articles that reflected their politics, posted images of loved ones and sent out messages of frustration or exultation. As social media platforms evolved, so did the way people used them. What started as a way to connect with friends and family soon turned into a global phenomenon, with people sharing their thoughts, opinions, and experiences with a vast audience. The rise of social media also led to the creation of online communities, where people could come together to discuss topics of common interest, share knowledge, and support one another.

However, as social media became more widespread, concerns began to arise about the impact it was having on society. Critics argued that the constant stream of information was overwhelming and distracting, making it difficult for people to focus on the present moment. Others worried about the spread of misinformation and the erosion of traditional forms of communication.

Despite these concerns, social media continued to grow in popularity, with millions of people around the world using platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with others and share their thoughts. The rise of social media also led to the creation of new forms of content, such as vlogs, podcasts, and live streams, which allowed people to share their experiences and perspectives with a global audience.

In recent years, social media has also become a key tool for businesses and organizations, allowing them to reach a wider audience and build brand awareness. Many companies now use social media to promote their products and services, engage with customers, and share their company culture.

Despite the many benefits of social media, there are still concerns about its impact on society. Some worry about the spread of misinformation, the erosion of traditional forms of communication, and the potential for social media to be used as a tool for manipulation and propaganda.

As social media continues to evolve, it is likely that these concerns will only grow. However, it is also clear that social media has the potential to be a powerful tool for good, allowing people to connect with one another, share their thoughts and experiences, and build communities around common interests.

Ultimately, the impact of social media on society will depend on how we choose to use it. By being mindful of the potential risks and benefits, and by using social media in a responsible and ethical way, we can harness its power to build a more connected and compassionate world.

House prices are still going up around the UK, and despite low mortgage rates increasing numbers of people are locked out of the property market. The problem is particularly acute for ethnic minorities, with figures showing those from BME backgrounds are much less likely to be homeowners than white Britons. According to a recent report by the National Housing Federation, the average house price in the UK has risen by 2.5% in the past year, with prices in London and the South East increasing by as much as 5%. This has led to a significant increase in the number of people who are struggling to get onto the property ladder.

The report also highlighted the stark disparities in homeownership rates between ethnic minorities and white Britons. Figures from the UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS) show that just 23% of people from Black and Minority Ethnic (BME) backgrounds own their own home, compared to 64% of white Britons.

This gap is particularly pronounced in certain regions, such as London, where only 15% of BME households own their own home, compared to 45% of white households. In other areas, such as the North East, the gap is smaller, but still significant, with 31% of BME households owning their own home, compared to 54% of white households.

The reasons for this disparity are complex and multifaceted, but experts point to a range of factors, including discriminatory practices in the mortgage market, lack of affordable housing options, and limited access to financial support.

One of the key challenges facing BME households is the difficulty in securing a mortgage. Research by the charity Shelter has found that BME households are more likely to be rejected for a mortgage than white households, even when they have similar credit profiles. This is due in part to the fact that many mortgage lenders use biased algorithms that are more likely to reject applications from BME households.

In addition, many BME households struggle to access affordable housing options. A report by the London School of Economics found that BME households are more likely to live in overcrowded or poor condition housing, and are less likely to have access to green spaces or community facilities.

The government has announced plans to address these disparities, including a new initiative to increase the number of affordable housing options available to BME households. The initiative, which is being piloted in several London boroughs, will provide financial support to BME households who are struggling to get onto the property ladder.

In addition, the government has pledged to work with mortgage lenders to address the issue of biased algorithms and to increase transparency in the mortgage application process. However, many experts argue that more needs to be done to address the root causes of the problem, including a lack of affordable housing options and limited access to financial support.

As the UK's housing market continues to rise, it is clear that more needs to be done to address the disparities faced by BME households. By providing affordable housing options and increasing access to financial support, the government can help to ensure that all households, regardless of ethnicity, have the opportunity to own their own home.

John Lewis and Debenhams are among the high street names backing a new credit union for the retail sector, officially launching today, which aims to help shop workers "avoid the clutches" of payday lenders. Another supporter is former Dragons' Den star Theo Paphitis, who once again got to say "I'm in", after revealing that he and his companies have invested a six-figure sum in the not-for-profit enterprise. Credit unions are financial co-operatives owned and controlled by their members that have traditionally specialised in loans and savings for the less well-off, but are now targeting people of all incomes. They are seen as offering a vital alternative to banks, expensive payday lenders and loan sharks, and the launch of this latest union, called retailCURe, is a big boost for the sector. The new credit union, retailCURe, aims to provide affordable financial services to retail workers, who are often vulnerable to the high-interest rates and fees charged by payday lenders. According to a recent study, over 1.2 million retail workers in the UK are currently using payday lenders to make ends meet, with many being forced to pay exorbitant rates of interest and fees.

RetailCURe is hoping to change this trend by offering competitive loan rates and savings accounts to its members. The credit union will also provide financial education and support to help retail workers manage their finances and avoid debt. "We're excited to be launching retailCURe, which will provide a vital lifeline to retail workers who are struggling to make ends meet," said Theo Paphitis, one of the key backers of the initiative.

The credit union has already gained the support of several major high street brands, including John Lewis and Debenhams, which will be providing financial backing and expertise to help get the initiative off the ground. "We're proud to be supporting retailCURe, which will help our colleagues and customers avoid the clutches of payday lenders," said a spokesperson for John Lewis.

The launch of retailCURe is seen as a major boost for the credit union sector, which has traditionally focused on serving low-income communities. However, with the rise of payday lending and loan sharks, there is now a growing recognition of the need for affordable financial services to be available to people of all incomes.

RetailCURe is the latest in a series of credit unions to launch in the UK, which have been growing in popularity in recent years. According to the Association of British Credit Unions, the number of credit union members in the UK has risen by over 20% in the past year alone.

The launch of retailCURe is expected to be a major milestone in the development of the credit union sector, which is seen as a vital alternative to traditional banking and financial services. With the support of major high street brands and a growing number of members, retailCURe is well-placed to make a significant impact in the lives of retail workers across the UK.

Surveys of consumer and business confidence in recent weeks have plummeted to recession-era lows. With such uncertainty, businesses have also recently curtailed spending on capital investments like computers, delivery trucks and other equipment, apparently in anticipation of higher tax rates and the destructive side effects of government cutbacks. Given that capital expenditures have been weak recently, some economists believe businesses will start spending more if Congress ends or at least delays the risk of severe fiscal tightening. "You would think there must be for most businesses a list of projects they'd like to do which they've just been pushing a little bit into the future because they haven't been able to justify taking the risk because they don't know what's around the corner," said Nigel Gault, chief United States economist for IHS Global Insight. According to Gault, if Congress can provide a clearer picture of the country's fiscal future, businesses may feel more confident in their investments, leading to an increase in capital expenditures. This, in turn, could have a positive impact on the overall economy.

Gault's sentiments are echoed by other economists, who point out that businesses have been holding back on investments due to the uncertainty surrounding the tax code and government spending. "The lack of clarity on the tax front is making it difficult for businesses to make long-term plans," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics. "If Congress can provide some certainty, we could see a boost in capital expenditures, which would be a positive sign for the economy."

The impact of weak capital expenditures is already being felt in certain industries. For example, the construction industry has seen a significant decline in investment in recent months, with many builders and developers putting projects on hold until the uncertainty surrounding the tax code is resolved.

However, not all economists are optimistic about the potential for an increase in capital expenditures. Some argue that the underlying issues driving the decline in confidence are too deep-seated to be addressed solely through Congressional action. "The problem is not just a lack of clarity on the tax front, it's also a lack of confidence in the overall direction of the economy," said Diane Swonk, chief economist at DS Economics. "Until we see some meaningful progress on the deficit and debt, I'm not sure that businesses will be willing to take on significant new investments."

Despite these concerns, many economists believe that an increase in capital expenditures would be a positive sign for the economy. "Capital expenditures are a key driver of economic growth, and if businesses start investing again, it could have a significant impact on the overall economy," said Gault. "It's not a silver bullet, but it's an important step in the right direction."

As Congress continues to debate the future of the tax code and government spending, businesses and economists alike will be watching closely for signs of a shift in policy. If Congress can provide the clarity and certainty that businesses are seeking, it could be a major boost for the economy. But if the uncertainty continues, it could have far-reaching consequences for businesses and consumers alike.

Hundreds of Apple workers across Europe who were employed to check Siri recordings for errors have lost their jobs after the company announced it was suspending the programme earlier this month. More than 300 employees have had their contracts ended in the company's Cork facility alone, according to former employees, with more sent home from other sites across Europe. The staff had been on paid leave since 2 August, the day Apple announced its decision to suspend the programme, referred to as "grading", as it conducted "a thorough review". The decision followed a story in the Guardian that revealed the workers frequently heard confidential medical information and couples having sex while checking the Siri recordings. The graders, employed through contracting firms, were sent home that Friday, with many told there was no work for them due to "technical errors". The sudden termination of the grading program has left many former employees reeling, with some expressing concerns about the sudden loss of income and the uncertainty surrounding their future employment prospects.

"I was told there was no work for me due to technical errors, but I know that's not the truth," said one former grader, who wished to remain anonymous. "We were doing our jobs, and then suddenly we were sent home without any explanation. It's been a nightmare trying to find new work, and I'm worried about how I'll pay my bills."

The grading program, which was launched in 2015, was designed to ensure the accuracy and quality of Siri's responses. The graders, who were employed through contracting firms, listened to recordings of Siri conversations and identified errors, such as mispronunciations or incorrect answers. However, the program has been plagued by controversy in recent years, with many workers complaining about the emotional toll of listening to sensitive and disturbing conversations.

The Guardian's investigation, which revealed that graders were frequently exposed to confidential medical information and intimate conversations, sparked widespread outrage and calls for Apple to improve its handling of the program. The company's decision to suspend the program was seen as a major victory for the workers, who had been fighting for better working conditions and more transparency.

When people tell you, "wake up and smell the roses," they might be giving you bad advice. Your sense of smell may fluctuate in sensitivity over the course of 24 hours, in tune with our circadian clocks, with your nose best able to do its job during the hours before you go to sleep, according to a study published last month. Researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) conducted the study, which involved 300 participants who were asked to identify a series of scents at different times of the day. The results showed that the participants' ability to detect and distinguish between different smells was significantly better in the evening, around 8-10 pm, compared to other times of the day.

"This is the first study to demonstrate that our sense of smell is regulated by our internal clock," said Dr. Jay Gottfried, the lead author of the study. "Our findings have important implications for how we think about the sense of smell and its role in our daily lives."

The researchers believe that the fluctuations in our sense of smell may be linked to the natural fluctuations in our body's levels of certain hormones, such as cortisol and melatonin. These hormones play a crucial role in regulating our sleep-wake cycles and may also influence our sense of smell.

The study's findings could have practical applications in a range of fields, from medicine to marketing. For example, healthcare professionals may need to consider the timing of scent-based therapies, such as aromatherapy, to maximize their effectiveness. Similarly, advertisers may need to rethink their use of scents in marketing campaigns, as the effectiveness of a particular scent may vary depending on the time of day.

The study's results also raise interesting questions about the relationship between our sense of smell and our brain's ability to process and remember different smells. While the study did not directly address these questions, the researchers plan to investigate them further in future studies.

In the meantime, the study's findings offer a fascinating insight into the complex and dynamic nature of our sense of smell. So, the next time someone tells you to "wake up and smell the roses," you might want to consider the timing of your rose-sniffing activities.

Further automation of the retail sector raises issues far beyond the needless luxuries of choice, convenience and speed of delivery (Amazon to test drone deliveries in British skies, 27 July). I wonder if the "demand" for stuff to be delivered by robot to our door within 30 minutes of ordering really exists – is modern satisfaction really that shallow? But in an increasingly automated society, where are the wages to buy these goods going to come from? As the retail sector continues to evolve, the question of where the wages will come from to purchase these goods becomes increasingly pressing. With automation taking over many tasks, including those traditionally performed by humans, the traditional employment model is being turned on its head.

According to a recent report by the International Labor Organization (ILO), the rise of automation is expected to displace up to 80 million jobs globally by 2030. While some of these jobs may be replaced by new ones, the ILO warns that many of the new jobs created will be low-skilled and low-paying, exacerbating income inequality.

In the United States, for example, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that between 2000 and 2016, the share of income going to the top 1% of earners increased from 13% to 21%, while the share going to the bottom 90% decreased from 64% to 49%. This trend is expected to continue, with automation and artificial intelligence (AI) potentially widening the wealth gap even further.

The consequences of this are far-reaching. As wages stagnate and income inequality grows, the ability of people to afford the goods and services they need to live decent lives becomes increasingly precarious. This is particularly concerning for low-income households, who are already struggling to make ends meet.

Furthermore, the rise of automation is also having a profound impact on the way we work and live. With more tasks being performed by machines, the concept of a traditional 9-to-5 job is becoming increasingly outdated. This is leading to a shift towards a gig economy, where workers are forced to constantly juggle multiple jobs to make ends meet.

In this new economy, the notion of a stable income and benefits package is becoming a luxury of the past. Instead, workers are being forced to rely on platforms like Uber and TaskRabbit to make a living, with all the uncertainty and insecurity that comes with it.

As we move forward in this increasingly automated society, it is crucial that we address these issues head-on. This means implementing policies that promote fair wages, social welfare programs, and education and training initiatives that prepare workers for the changing job market.

It also means rethinking our values and priorities as a society. Do we truly value the convenience and speed of delivery that comes with automation, or do we prioritize the well-being and dignity of human workers? The answer to this question will determine the kind of society we build in the years to come.

However, Eramo's lawyers have pointed out that the article's reporting was marred by numerous errors and inconsistencies, and that the magazine's fact-checking process was inadequate. The trial is expected to continue for several more days, with both sides presenting evidence and witnesses. The outcome of the trial could have significant implications for Rolling Stone and the media industry as a whole, as it will set a precedent for how libel lawsuits are handled in the future.

The controversy surrounding WhatsApp's data sharing practices is likely to continue in the coming weeks and months. Q. How safe is it to give smart gadgets the password to my Wi-Fi network? Should I be worried and what can I do? The Rise of Smart Homes: Is Sharing Your Wi-Fi Password a Risk Worth Taking?

In today's interconnected world, smart gadgets have become an integral part of our daily lives. From smart thermostats to voice assistants, these devices make our lives easier and more convenient. However, with the increasing reliance on Wi-Fi connectivity, a pressing question has emerged: is it safe to give smart gadgets the password to your Wi-Fi network?

The answer is not a simple yes or no. While sharing your Wi-Fi password with smart gadgets can provide seamless connectivity and convenience, it also poses significant security risks. With the password, hackers can gain unauthorized access to your network, compromising your personal data and online activities.

One of the primary concerns is the potential for data breaches. Smart gadgets, especially those with internet connectivity, can collect and transmit sensitive information, such as browsing history, search queries, and personal messages. If your Wi-Fi password is compromised, hackers can intercept this data, putting your privacy at risk.

Another concern is the vulnerability of smart gadgets to malware and viruses. Many smart devices are not designed with robust security measures, making them susceptible to hacking and exploitation. If your Wi-Fi password is shared with these devices, hackers can use them as a gateway to infiltrate your network and spread malware.

So, should you be worried? The answer is yes. However, there are steps you can take to minimize the risks:

1. Use strong and unique passwords for each smart gadget. Avoid using the same password for multiple devices to prevent a single breach from compromising all your devices.
2. Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) whenever possible. This adds an extra layer of security by requiring a second form of verification, such as a code sent to your phone, in addition to your password.
3. Regularly update your smart gadgets' firmware and software to ensure you have the latest security patches and features.
4. Consider using a virtual private network (VPN) to encrypt your internet traffic and protect your data from prying eyes.
5. Limit access to your Wi-Fi network by setting up a guest network for visitors and restricting access to specific devices.

In conclusion, while sharing your Wi-Fi password with smart gadgets can provide convenience, it is essential to weigh the risks against the benefits. By taking proactive steps to secure your network and devices, you can minimize the risks and enjoy the benefits of smart home technology while maintaining your online security and privacy.

Six of the biggest American technology firms have combined forces to call for major changes to the Investigatory Powers bill, commonly known as the snooper's charter. The firms warn that "important amendments are required" to create a bill that will not set dangerous precedents "which may be copied elsewhere and have wider ramifications for all parties, both in the UK and overseas". Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Twitter and Yahoo, who had teamed up for an earlier group submission, were joined for the first time by Apple, which had previously insisted on going it alone in its efforts to lobby the British parliament. The tech giants' joint statement, which was submitted to the UK Parliament's Intelligence and Security Committee, highlights several concerns regarding the Investigatory Powers bill. One of the main issues is the lack of clear safeguards to prevent the government from abusing its powers to access personal data.

The companies argue that the bill's language is too broad and could lead to the government collecting and storing vast amounts of data without proper justification. They also express concern that the bill does not provide adequate protections for data stored outside of the UK, which could lead to conflicts with international data protection laws.

Another major issue raised by the tech firms is the bill's requirement for internet companies to retain user data for up to a year. They argue that this would create a significant burden on their infrastructure and could lead to increased costs for consumers.

The companies are also concerned about the bill's provisions for hacking and cyber-attacks. They argue that the bill's language is too vague and could lead to the government using its powers to engage in activities that could be considered illegal under other circumstances.

In addition to these specific concerns, the tech firms are also worried about the potential impact of the bill on the global internet. They argue that if the UK sets a precedent for mass surveillance, it could lead to a slippery slope where other countries follow suit, potentially leading to a loss of privacy and freedom for individuals around the world.

The joint statement from the tech giants is seen as a significant blow to the government's plans to pass the Investigatory Powers bill in its current form. The bill is currently making its way through the UK Parliament, and it is expected to be debated and voted on in the coming weeks.

The government has previously defended the bill, arguing that it is necessary to keep the country safe from terrorism and other threats. However, the tech firms' concerns have raised questions about the bill's impact on privacy and individual freedoms.

As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the government will be able to address the tech firms' concerns and pass the bill in its current form. However, one thing is clear: the Investigatory Powers bill has sparked a major debate about the balance between national security and individual privacy, and it is likely to have far-reaching implications for the future of the internet and online communication.

The UK government has also been taking steps to improve the security of internet-connected devices. The proposed bill would require manufacturers to take certain steps to improve the security of their devices, including conducting regular security testing and providing clear information about the security of their products. It would also give the government the power to impose fines on manufacturers that fail to comply with the new regulations.

The proposal has been welcomed by cybersecurity experts, who argue that it would help to reduce the number of vulnerabilities that can be exploited by cybercriminals. "The proposed Cybersecurity Bill is a step in the right direction," said Dr. Jones. "It would help to raise the bar for manufacturers and provide consumers with greater peace of mind when buying internet-connected devices."

Drip water on a hot pan, and the droplets will skitter around the pan, speeding like tiny mad hovercraft on cushions of steam. This is the Leidenfrost effect, which you've probably experienced while cooking. Johann Gottlob Leidenfrost, a German doctor and theologian, described the phenomenon in 1756 in a book about the properties of water. But French scientists have now figured out something new about those skittering drops. When they are small enough -- about a millimeter in diameter -- the roiling of heat in the liquid will cause the droplet to tilt and rotate. That, in turn, propels the droplet to roll. Scientists -- and home cooks -- never noticed this before, because no one had tried pinning a water droplet on a precisely flat surface. Plus, since water is clear, you usually can't see which way the liquid is churning. It was already known that the droplets, levitating on top of a layer of vapor, move easily, but the presumption was that they were sliding down a slope or pushed by air currents. This breakthrough discovery has significant implications for various fields, including engineering, physics, and even medicine. The researchers at the French institution, using advanced imaging techniques, were able to visualize the previously unknown behavior of the water droplets. They found that the rotation and tilting of the droplets creates a unique pattern of movement, which could be exploited to develop new technologies.

One potential application is in the design of more efficient heat transfer systems. By understanding how the droplets move and interact with their surroundings, engineers could develop new materials and surfaces that maximize heat transfer while minimizing energy loss. This could have significant benefits in industries such as power generation, aerospace, and automotive manufacturing.

The discovery also has potential implications for the field of medicine. Researchers are exploring the possibility of using the Leidenfrost effect to develop new methods for delivering targeted doses of medication or therapy to specific areas of the body. By harnessing the unique properties of the water droplets, scientists may be able to create more effective and efficient delivery systems for a range of medical treatments.

The French scientists' findings have also sparked interest in the field of fluid dynamics, where researchers are working to better understand the complex interactions between fluids and surfaces. The discovery of the tilting and rotation of the water droplets has opened up new avenues for research, and scientists are eager to explore the potential applications of this phenomenon.

In addition to its scientific significance, the discovery has also captured the imagination of the general public. The visualization of the Leidenfrost effect has been shared widely on social media, and many people are fascinated by the mesmerizing images of the water droplets in motion. The discovery has also sparked a renewed interest in the fundamental properties of water and the ways in which it interacts with its surroundings.

As researchers continue to explore the implications of this discovery, it is clear that the Leidenfrost effect has the potential to revolutionize a range of fields and industries. From engineering and medicine to physics and beyond, the unique properties of the water droplets are opening up new possibilities for innovation and discovery.

According to experts, the product's capabilities are a direct result of the research and development conducted by Chronicle's team in the aftermath of the 2009 Google hack.

The 2009 attack, which was attributed to Chinese military hackers, was a significant wake-up call for the tech industry. It marked one of the first times that a major American company had been targeted by a foreign government in such a brazen manner. The incident led to widespread concerns about the vulnerability of corporate networks and the potential for future attacks.

Chronicle's Backstory product is designed to address these concerns by providing companies with a comprehensive platform for detecting and responding to advanced threats. The product uses machine learning and artificial intelligence to analyze large amounts of data and identify patterns that may indicate a cyber attack.

"We've learned a lot from our own experiences with cyber attacks, including the 2009 incident," said Stephen Gillett, CEO of Chronicle. "We've taken those lessons and applied them to the development of Backstory, which is designed to help companies detect and respond to even the most sophisticated threats."

These industries are often targeted by nation-state actors and other advanced threat actors due to the sensitive nature of the data they handle.

The product is also designed to be highly scalable, allowing companies of all sizes to use it to protect their networks. Chronicle has already partnered with several major companies to test the product, and it is expected to be widely available later this year.

The announcement of Backstory comes at a time when cyber attacks are becoming increasingly sophisticated and frequent. In recent years, there have been numerous high-profile attacks on major companies, including Equifax, Yahoo, and Target.

As a result, companies are increasingly looking for new and innovative ways to protect their networks and data. Chronicle's Backstory product is designed to meet this need, and its announcement is likely to be closely watched by the tech industry.

In a statement, Google's CEO Sundar Pichai praised the development of Backstory, saying that it was an important step in the fight against cyber attacks. "We're committed to using our expertise and resources to help protect our customers and the broader tech industry from cyber threats," he said. The number of individuals applying for insolvency jumped to the highest level in almost three years in the first three months of 2017, in a further sign of the mounting financial pressure facing UK households. Personal insolvencies in England and Wales totalled 24,531 between January and March, up 6.7% on the previous quarter and 15.7% higher than the same period a year earlier. It was the highest number of individual cases since the second quarter of 2014, according to the Insolvency Service, which published the figures. The rise in personal insolvencies has been attributed to a combination of factors, including stagnant wages, rising living costs, and increased debt levels. The Insolvency Service's figures show that the majority of insolvency cases (63%) were attributed to debt problems, with the remaining 37% caused by other factors such as business failures or financial difficulties.

The data also reveals that the number of individuals seeking debt relief orders (DROs) increased by 14.5% compared to the same period last year, with 10,444 DROs issued in the first quarter of 2017. DROs are a type of insolvency procedure that allows individuals to write off up to £20,000 of unsecured debt and are often used by those who are struggling to pay their bills.

The Insolvency Service's director, Sean Feeney, warned that the figures are a "cause for concern" and highlighted the need for individuals to seek advice and support to manage their debt. "We urge anyone struggling with debt to seek help and advice from a qualified debt advisor or a charity such as StepChange Debt Charity," he said.

The rise in personal insolvencies has also been linked to the UK's economic uncertainty, with many individuals feeling anxious about their financial security due to the ongoing Brexit negotiations. The Bank of England has also warned that the UK's economic growth is expected to slow down in the coming months, which could exacerbate the problem.

Experts are calling for urgent action to address the issue, including measures to improve financial education and increase access to affordable credit. "The government needs to take a more proactive role in addressing the root causes of debt and providing support to those who are struggling," said Mike O'Connor, chief executive of StepChange Debt Charity.

In the meantime, individuals who are struggling with debt are being advised to seek help and support as soon as possible. The Insolvency Service offers a range of services to help individuals manage their debt, including debt advice and debt relief orders. Additionally, there are a number of charities and organizations that offer free or low-cost debt advice and support.

As the UK's economic uncertainty continues to affect households, the rise in personal insolvencies is a stark reminder of the need for individuals to prioritize their financial well-being and seek help when needed.

The rise of streaming has fractured the television audience, and it has become a rarity for a show to draw more than 20 million viewers. The shift towards streaming has been a major factor in this decline. Many viewers are opting to watch their favorite shows and events online, rather than tuning in to traditional television. This has led to a fragmentation of the audience, with viewers spread across multiple platforms and devices.

Despite this trend, some shows are still managing to attract large audiences. The latest season of the popular drama "Stranger Things" on Netflix, for example, drew an estimated 64 million viewers in its first four weeks of release. Similarly, the HBO series "Game of Thrones" consistently drew audiences of over 10 million viewers per episode in its final season.

However, even these shows are not immune to the effects of streaming. According to a survey by the market research firm Deloitte, 70% of respondents said they use streaming services to watch TV shows, with 40% saying they use them exclusively.

The decline in traditional TV viewership is also having a significant impact on the advertising industry. With fewer viewers tuning in to traditional TV, advertisers are being forced to rethink their strategies and allocate their budgets to other platforms.

Despite these challenges, many TV networks are still holding out hope that traditional TV will make a comeback. Some are investing heavily in new content and formats, in an effort to attract and retain viewers. Others are exploring new ways to monetize their content, such as through subscription-based services.

However, it's unclear whether these efforts will be enough to stem the tide of decline. As more and more viewers turn to streaming, it's likely that traditional TV will continue to struggle to compete. The future of television is likely to be a hybrid model, with viewers consuming content across multiple platforms and devices.

In the meantime, TV networks and advertisers will need to adapt to this new reality and find new ways to reach and engage with their audiences. As the streaming wars continue to rage on, one thing is clear: the way we watch TV is changing forever.

Out with pizza, in with poke bowls. That's the new culinary strategy at Kent State and Cornell University, which this school year rolled out the first certified gluten-free dining halls. An estimated 5 to 10 percent of college students have celiac disease or other gluten-related disorders, according to Dr. Alessio Fasano, director of the Center for Celiac Research and Treatment in Boston. The move is a significant step towards providing a more inclusive and accommodating dining experience for students with dietary restrictions. Both Kent State and Cornell University have partnered with food service providers to offer a wide range of gluten-free options, including poke bowls, salads, and sandwiches.

According to Kent State's dining services, the university's new gluten-free hall features a dedicated station serving gluten-free pasta, pizza, and other dishes. The hall also offers a variety of gluten-free bread and baked goods, making it easier for students with gluten intolerance to find options that fit their dietary needs.

Cornell University's gluten-free dining hall, on the other hand, features a global cuisine menu with dishes inspired by international flavors. The hall offers a variety of gluten-free options, including stir-fries, curries, and noodle dishes. Students can also customize their meals by asking for gluten-free substitutions or modifications.

Both universities have also implemented strict protocols to prevent cross-contamination with gluten-containing foods. This includes separate cooking and preparation areas, as well as dedicated gluten-free utensils and equipment.

Dr. Fasano, who has been studying celiac disease and gluten-related disorders for over two decades, praised the efforts of both universities. "It's fantastic to see institutions taking proactive steps to accommodate students with gluten-related disorders," he said. "By providing gluten-free options and implementing proper protocols, these universities are not only supporting students' health but also promoting inclusivity and diversity on campus."

The move is also seen as a significant step towards reducing the stigma surrounding gluten-related disorders. According to Dr. Fasano, many students with gluten intolerance or celiac disease often feel like they are forced to choose between their health and their social life. By providing gluten-free options, universities can help students feel more included and supported.

The Crop Protection Association (CPA) criticises the RSA Food, Farming and Countryside Commission report, Our Future in the Land, for its absence of science (Letters, 22 July). Good science is a rigorous and critical process of inquiry: it is far from perfect, neutral and incontrovertible. The CPA's criticism of the RSA report is a valid one, as it is essential to base policy decisions on sound scientific evidence. The report's authors may have relied too heavily on anecdotal evidence and personal opinions, rather than conducting rigorous research and analysis.

Moreover, the CPA is correct in pointing out that good science is a continuous process of inquiry, refinement, and adaptation. It is not a static entity that can be relied upon to provide definitive answers. Scientific knowledge is constantly evolving, and new discoveries can often challenge existing theories and findings.

In the context of crop protection, this means that any policy decisions or recommendations should be grounded in the latest scientific research and understanding of the complex interactions between crops, pests, and the environment. The CPA's expertise in this area is undeniable, and their criticism of the RSA report serves as a reminder of the importance of evidence-based decision-making.

However, it is also important to recognize that the RSA report was not intended to be a definitive scientific treatise, but rather a thought-provoking exploration of the future of food, farming, and the countryside. The report's authors drew on a wide range of perspectives and expertise, including those from the farming community, environmental organizations, and consumer groups.

Ultimately, the debate surrounding the RSA report is a welcome one, as it highlights the need for ongoing dialogue and collaboration between scientists, policymakers, and stakeholders. By engaging in a critical and constructive discussion of the issues, we can work towards developing more effective and sustainable solutions for the future of our food system.

In conclusion, while the CPA's criticism of the RSA report is justified, it is essential to recognize the report's value as a catalyst for discussion and debate. By embracing a more nuanced and evidence-based approach to policy-making, we can work towards a more sustainable and resilient food system that benefits both people and the planet.

Q. How does my phone know to flip the screen around? "Q. How does my phone know to flip the screen around?

A. It's a common phenomenon that has left many of us wondering - how does our phone know to automatically flip the screen when we rotate it? The answer lies in the clever combination of sensors and software that work together to detect the orientation of our device.

The primary sensor responsible for this functionality is the accelerometer, which measures the phone's acceleration and orientation in three-dimensional space. This data is then used by the phone's operating system to determine the device's position and orientation.

When you rotate your phone, the accelerometer detects the change in acceleration and sends the data to the phone's processor. The processor then uses this information to trigger the screen rotation, ensuring that the display remains upright and readable regardless of the device's orientation.

But that's not all - other sensors also play a crucial role in ensuring seamless screen rotation. The gyroscope, for instance, measures the phone's rotational velocity and orientation, providing additional data to the processor to refine the screen rotation.

The phone's operating system also plays a vital role in this process. The OS uses the data from the sensors to determine the device's orientation and adjusts the screen accordingly. This is achieved through a combination of algorithms and software tweaks that ensure a smooth and seamless user experience.

In addition to the accelerometer and gyroscope, some phones also employ additional sensors such as the magnetometer, which measures the phone's magnetic field and helps to further refine the screen rotation.

In conclusion, the ability of our phones to automatically flip the screen around is a testament to the impressive advancements in sensor technology and software engineering. By combining the data from multiple sensors and clever algorithms, our phones are able to detect and respond to changes in orientation with remarkable accuracy and speed."

My father, Edgar Young, who has died aged 93, was part of an extraordinary postwar intake at Bognor Regis emergency teacher training college in West Sussex. Created to address the severe teacher shortage following Rab Butler's 1944 Education Act, the college, led by the innovative Roy Macklin, was more concerned with the character and experience of applicants than in formal qualifications. During the second world war, Edgar had worked in a protected occupation as a shipwright in Portsmouth dockyard, but saw a vocation in primary school teaching and shared Macklin's view of education as a guide for living rather than narrowly vocational or academic. The college provided an intensive 50-week course for mature students, mainly former servicemen and women. Possessing practical skills and often widely travelled, they brought to the classroom a wealth of knowledge denied to colleagues whose life had been spent wholly in the education system. Edgar's experience at Bognor Regis emergency teacher training college was transformative. The college's emphasis on character and experience allowed him to bring his unique perspective to the classroom. His background in shipbuilding and his wartime experiences gave him a deep understanding of the importance of practical skills and teamwork, which he was able to share with his students.

After completing his training, Edgar began his teaching career at a primary school in Portsmouth. He quickly established himself as a popular and effective teacher, known for his ability to engage his students and make complex concepts accessible. His approach to teaching was holistic, focusing on the development of the whole child, rather than just their academic abilities.

Edgar's teaching career spanned over three decades, during which he worked with thousands of students. He was particularly proud of his work with children from disadvantaged backgrounds, and was dedicated to helping them reach their full potential. His passion for teaching and his commitment to his students earned him numerous awards and recognition from his peers and the community.

In addition to his teaching career, Edgar was also an active member of his local community. He served on the board of governors at his local school, and was involved in various charitable organizations. He was also a keen sportsman, and enjoyed playing cricket and sailing in his spare time.

Edgar is survived by his wife, Margaret, and their two children, Jane and Michael. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, and the countless students whose lives he touched through his teaching.

Every week a Guardian Money reader submits a question, and it's up to you to help him or her out – a selection of the best answers will appear in next Saturday's paper. We have always fancied a hot tub, but never had the money. The quest for a relaxing soak in a hot tub is a common dream for many of us. For one Guardian Money reader, the desire for a warm and bubbly retreat has been a long-held aspiration, but one that has been put on the backburner due to financial constraints. However, with a little creativity and some savvy research, it's possible to turn this dream into a reality.

Firstly, it's essential to consider the cost of a hot tub. While a high-end model can set you back thousands of pounds, there are more affordable options available. For instance, a basic hot tub can be purchased for around £500-£1,000, while a more advanced model with extra features like massage jets and chromotherapy can cost upwards of £2,000-£3,000.

Another option is to consider buying a used or refurbished hot tub. Many online retailers and hot tub dealerships offer certified pre-owned models at a significant discount. Additionally, some manufacturers offer refurbished or demo models that have been thoroughly inspected and tested, which can be a great way to get a high-quality hot tub at a lower price point.

For those on a tight budget, it's worth considering alternative options. A portable hot tub, also known as a "pool", can be a great alternative to a traditional hot tub. These inflatable tubs are designed for relaxation and can be set up in a backyard or even indoors. They're often more affordable, with prices starting from around £100-£300.

It's also important to think about the running costs of a hot tub. While the initial purchase price may be the biggest expense, there are ongoing costs to consider, such as electricity, water, and maintenance. To minimize these costs, it's essential to choose a hot tub with energy-efficient features and to regularly clean and maintain the tub to prevent damage and extend its lifespan.

For our reader, who is looking to install a hot tub in their backyard, there are a few things to consider. Firstly, it's essential to check with local authorities to ensure that hot tubs are allowed in the area and to obtain any necessary permits. Additionally, it's important to choose a location that is level, well-drained, and close to a power source.

Finally, it's worth considering the benefits of a hot tub beyond just relaxation. Many people find that soaking in a hot tub can help alleviate stress, improve sleep, and even provide relief from chronic pain. With the right mindset and a little creativity, a hot tub can become a valuable addition to any home.

In conclusion, while a hot tub may seem like a luxury item, it's possible to make it a reality with a little research and planning. Whether you opt for a basic model or a high-end luxury tub, the benefits of relaxation and rejuvenation are well worth the investment.

Stuart Rose, the former M&S boss installed as chairman of the Britain Stronger in Europe remain campaign, has blamed the leave victory on voters' anger with distant politicians and a loss of trust in big business. "I'm not a politician and this was always going to be a battle won or lost by politicians, and a reflection of the bigger things going on the world," said Lord Rose. "People are clearly unhappy with the current state of affairs. They want to be listened to and want change – that's a political issue." Asked if the country's captains of industry could have done more to convince voters to back the status quo, he pointed to disaffection between the "man in the street and big business". Lord Rose's comments come as the country is still reeling from the shock of the Brexit vote, which saw 51.9% of voters opt to leave the European Union. The businessman, who led Marks & Spencer from 2004 to 2011, has been a vocal critic of the Leave campaign and had previously warned of the potential economic risks of a Brexit.

Despite his own reservations, Lord Rose believes that the outcome of the referendum was a reflection of deeper societal issues. "The anger and frustration that people felt was not just about Europe, it was about the sense that they're not being listened to, that they're not being heard," he said.

Lord Rose also pointed to the growing divide between the wealthy and the poor as a factor in the vote. "There's a sense that the system is rigged, that the game is being played by the people at the top, and that the ordinary person is not getting a fair deal," he said.

The former M&S boss also acknowledged that big business had a role to play in the outcome of the referendum. "I think there's been a loss of trust in big business, and I think that's a problem," he said. "We need to do more to demonstrate that we're on the side of the people, that we're not just looking after our own interests."

Lord Rose's comments come as the Britain Stronger in Europe campaign, which he chairs, is set to launch a new initiative aimed at rebuilding trust between business and the public. The campaign will focus on promoting the benefits of EU membership and highlighting the potential risks of a Brexit.

The former M&S boss is not the only business leader to express concerns about the outcome of the referendum. Many other CEOs and entrepreneurs have spoken out about the potential economic risks of a Brexit, including the founder of the coffee chain Costa, who warned that the vote could lead to a recession.

Despite the concerns, Lord Rose remains optimistic about the country's future. "I think we'll get through this, and I think we'll come out stronger on the other side," he said. "But we need to work together to make that happen."
