Many professors who have expressed their views about race and politics this year have found themselves targets of both the left and right. Nothing is too abstrusely academic, it seems, to seed an attack campaign fueled by websites that surveil social media to find gotcha-worthy gems. The Professor Watch List, for one, created last year by the conservative group Turning Point USA, is helping drive a new level of scrutiny of professors who, it says, "discriminate against conservative students and advance leftist propaganda in the classroom." Some sites even send out alerts to subscribers. The rise of online vigilantism has created a culture of fear and intimidation among academics, with many professors feeling compelled to self-censor their views to avoid being targeted. The Professor Watch List, which claims to have identified over 200 professors who allegedly promote "leftist propaganda" in their teaching, has been criticized for its lack of transparency and methodology.

Critics argue that the list is often based on incomplete or misleading information, and that it is being used to silence professors who are simply trying to engage their students in discussions about complex social issues. Many of the professors listed have spoken out against the list, saying that it is an attempt to intimidate and silence them.

"It's a form of intellectual McCarthyism," said Dr. Sarah Jones, a professor of sociology at a major university who was recently added to the list. "These groups are trying to create a climate of fear, where professors are too afraid to speak their minds or teach about controversial topics. It's a threat to academic freedom and the very fabric of our educational system."

The Professor Watch List is not the only group targeting professors. Other conservative organizations, such as Campus Reform, have also launched campaigns to expose and criticize professors who they deem to be liberal or left-leaning. These groups often use social media to spread their message, and have been accused of using tactics such as doxing and harassment to silence their targets.

The impact of these campaigns is being felt across the academic community. Many professors are now self-censoring their views, afraid to express opinions that may be seen as controversial or political. Others are facing backlash from students and colleagues who disagree with their views, and are struggling to maintain their academic freedom.

The situation is particularly concerning for professors of color, who are already underrepresented in academia. Many have spoken out about the pressure they feel to conform to traditional academic norms, and the fear of being targeted by online vigilantes.

"I've had to be very careful about what I say and do, because I know that I'm being watched," said Dr. Jamal Brown, a professor of African American studies at a major university. "It's a constant stress, knowing that I could be attacked or doxed at any moment. It's taking a toll on my mental and physical health, and it's making it harder for me to do my job."

As the situation continues to unfold, many are calling for action to be taken to protect academic freedom and prevent the silencing of professors. Some are advocating for legislation to protect professors from online harassment, while others are calling for universities to take a stronger stance against these campaigns.

Ultimately, the fate of academic freedom hangs in the balance. Will professors be able to continue to speak their minds and teach without fear of retribution, or will the pressure of online vigilantism continue to silence them? Only time will tell.

The scrutiny of Facebook's collection and use of consumer data in recent years has prompted the tech giant to repeatedly defend its efforts around transparency and privacy. But about three-fourths of Facebook users were unaware that the company lists their personal traits and interests for advertisers on its site, according to a study published by the Pew Research Center on Wednesday. Half of the users who looked at the Facebook page with that data -- known as their "Ad Preferences" -- said they were not comfortable with the company's compiling that information. The study, which surveyed over 1,000 Facebook users, found that only 27% of respondents were aware that Facebook collects and stores their personal traits and interests for advertising purposes. This lack of awareness is particularly concerning, as many users may not be aware of the extent to which their online activities are being tracked and used to target them with specific advertisements.

The Pew Research Center's findings highlight the need for greater transparency and accountability from Facebook and other social media companies. "Facebook's business model relies heavily on collecting and using user data to target advertisements," said Lee Rainie, director of internet and technology research at the Pew Research Center. "However, our study shows that many users are not aware of this practice, and that raises important questions about consent and privacy."

The study also found that younger Facebook users, aged 18-29, were more likely to be aware of Facebook's data collection practices than older users. However, even among this group, only 41% were aware of the company's compilation of their personal traits and interests.

Facebook has faced intense scrutiny in recent years over its handling of user data, including the Cambridge Analytica scandal, which involved the unauthorized sharing of millions of users' personal information. In response to the controversy, the company has implemented several measures aimed at increasing transparency and protecting user privacy, including the creation of a "Data Portal" that allows users to view and manage the data that Facebook collects about them.

However, the Pew Research Center's study suggests that more needs to be done to educate users about Facebook's data collection practices and to ensure that they have meaningful control over their personal data. "Facebook and other social media companies need to do a better job of explaining how they collect and use user data, and they need to provide users with more granular controls over their data," said Rainie.

The study's findings also have implications for policymakers, who are grappling with the issue of data privacy and the need for stronger regulations to protect users' personal information. "This study highlights the need for Congress to pass comprehensive data privacy legislation that protects the rights of consumers and holds companies accountable for their handling of user data," said Senator Ed Markey (D-MA), a leading advocate for data privacy reform.

In response to the study's findings, Facebook has reiterated its commitment to transparency and user privacy. "We take the privacy and security of our users' data very seriously, and we are committed to providing them with clear and transparent information about how we collect and use their data," said a Facebook spokesperson. "We will continue to work to improve our data practices and to provide users with more control over their data."

British adults are becoming less reliant on Facebook for communicating with friends, according to research conducted by the UK media regulator, which suggests people are starting to turn to other social media apps. The number of British social media users who consider Facebook to be their main social media or messaging profile fell from 80% to 70% in 12 months, according to the regulator's annual media use survey. Instead Britons are increasingly using other services, with the proportion of internet users considering WhatsApp to be their main online profile increasing from 7% to 16%. The shift away from Facebook is attributed to concerns over data privacy and the platform's handling of user data. The Cambridge Analytica scandal in 2018, where the political consulting firm harvested the data of millions of Facebook users without their consent, led to a significant loss of trust in the platform.

"The survey highlights a significant change in the way people are using social media," said a spokesperson for the UK media regulator. "While Facebook is still the most widely used social media platform in the UK, our data suggests that people are becoming increasingly wary of the company's handling of their personal data."

The regulator's survey also found that the proportion of internet users who consider Twitter to be their main online profile increased from 4% to 6% over the same period. Instagram, which is owned by Facebook, also saw an increase in users considering it their main online profile, from 5% to 7%.

However, the survey also revealed that the use of other social media platforms, such as TikTok and Snapchat, is on the rise. The proportion of internet users who consider TikTok to be their main online profile increased from 2% to 5%, while the proportion of users who consider Snapchat to be their main online profile increased from 3% to 5%.

The shift away from Facebook is also attributed to the rise of messaging apps, such as WhatsApp and Telegram, which offer a more private and secure way of communicating with friends and family. The survey found that the proportion of internet users who consider WhatsApp to be their main messaging app increased from 40% to 50% over the past year.

"The survey highlights the importance of data privacy and security in the way people use social media," said a digital rights expert. "As people become more aware of the risks associated with social media, they are looking for alternative platforms that offer greater control over their personal data."

The regulator's survey also found that the use of social media is becoming more fragmented, with people using multiple platforms to communicate with friends and family. The survey found that the average internet user uses three or more social media platforms, with 60% of users using two or more platforms.

The shift away from Facebook is likely to have significant implications for the company's business model, which relies heavily on advertising revenue. The company has been working to diversify its revenue streams, including the launch of new products and services, such as Facebook Dating and Facebook Gaming.

However, the shift away from Facebook is also likely to have significant implications for the wider social media industry, which is facing increasing scrutiny over issues such as data privacy and disinformation. The regulator's survey highlights the need for social media companies to prioritize data privacy and security, and to provide users with greater control over their personal data.

Rupert Murdoch has doubled the length of time he is willing to keep running Sky News to "at least" 10 years, as 21st Century Fox sweetens its offer to protect the news channel to gain clearance for the £11.7bn takeover of Sky. The Murdoch family trust controls Fox and News Corp, publisher of the Sun and the Times. Last week, Fox strengthened the so-called "firewall" remedies it had tabled but did not increase its original offer of guaranteeing to fund Sky News for a minimum of five years. The revised offer is expected to alleviate concerns over media plurality, but some experts believe it may not be enough to fully address the issue. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is expected to review the revised offer and may still require further concessions from Fox before giving the green light for the takeover. In the meantime, the fate of Sky News remains uncertain. The channel has been a key player in the UK's media landscape, providing independent coverage of major news events and investigative reporting. Its independence is seen as crucial to maintaining a balanced and diverse media ecosystem.

The Murdoch family's control over Sky News has raised concerns among media watchdogs and politicians. The UK's culture secretary, Jeremy Wright, has expressed concerns over the deal, saying that it could lead to a "concentration of power" in the hands of the Murdoch family. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has also weighed in, calling for the deal to be blocked due to the potential risks to media plurality.

Despite the controversy, Fox remains committed to the takeover and has expressed confidence that the deal will ultimately be approved. "We believe that our revised offer addresses the CMA's concerns and will allow us to move forward with the acquisition of Sky," said a Fox spokesperson. "We are committed to ensuring the long-term success and independence of Sky News, and we are confident that our proposal will be approved."

The outcome of the takeover is expected to have significant implications for the UK's media landscape, and the CMA's decision will be closely watched by media professionals, politicians, and the public alike.

The potential applications of this technology are vast. For example, the sensor could be used to monitor patients with diabetes, allowing for real-time tracking of glucose levels and early detection of potential complications. Similarly, the sensor could be used to monitor athletes, providing valuable insights into their physiological state and helping to prevent injuries and improve performance.

But more detailed data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed that consumers, hit by rising utility bills and transport costs, had to cope with almost static disposable incomes, forcing them to dip into savings to maintain their spending habits. The ONS reported that consumer spending, which accounts for around 60% of the UK's economic activity, rose by 0.4% in the third quarter of the year, the fastest pace in five years. However, this growth was largely driven by households using up their savings to fund their spending, rather than an increase in their disposable income.

The data also showed that businesses, on the other hand, continued to cut back on investment, with capital expenditure falling by 0.3% in the quarter. This is a worrying sign for the economy, as business investment is often seen as a key driver of long-term growth.

The ONS attributed the decline in business investment to ongoing uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the European Union. Many companies have been hesitant to invest in the UK due to the lack of clarity on the country's future trading relationships with the EU and other countries.

"The uncertainty surrounding Brexit is still affecting business investment, and it's clear that companies are being cautious about committing to new projects until the situation becomes clearer," said a spokesperson for the ONS.

The figures also showed that the UK's trade deficit widened to £13.1 billion in the third quarter, up from £10.7 billion in the previous quarter. This is a concern for the economy, as a large trade deficit can put pressure on the value of the pound and make imports more expensive.

Despite the challenges, the ONS remains optimistic about the UK's economic prospects. "While there are some signs of caution in the data, the UK's economy is still showing resilience and is likely to continue growing in the coming months," said the spokesperson.

The news comes as the UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Philip Hammond, prepares to deliver his autumn budget statement. Hammond is under pressure to provide more clarity on the government's plans for Brexit and to outline measures to support businesses and households affected by the uncertainty.

In the meantime, consumers will be keeping a close eye on their finances, with many struggling to make ends meet due to the rising cost of living. In 2014, for the first time, the nation's student body -- from kindergartners to 12th graders -- was majority-minority. And the change is spilling out into the nation's colleges and the country over all. Census data predicts that by 2050 the United States will be majority-minority as well. As I see these changes, I continue to ask, Are our college and university faculties ready to teach a diverse student body? The demographic shift in the United States is a topic of increasing concern for educators and policymakers alike. As the nation's student body becomes more diverse, it is imperative that college and university faculties reflect this change. However, a recent study by the American Council on Education found that faculty diversity has not kept pace with the growing diversity of students.

According to the study, in 2019, only 26% of full-time faculty members at degree-granting institutions were from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups, including Black, Hispanic, Asian, and Native American individuals. This is a significant decrease from the 1980s, when 35% of faculty members belonged to these groups.

The lack of diversity among faculty members can have far-reaching consequences for students. Research has shown that students who have diverse instructors are more likely to feel a sense of belonging and are more likely to succeed academically. Furthermore, diverse faculty members bring unique perspectives and experiences to the classroom, which can enrich the learning experience for all students.

So, what can be done to increase faculty diversity? One solution is to implement targeted recruitment and hiring practices. Many institutions are now actively seeking out candidates from underrepresented groups and providing them with support and resources to help them succeed. For example, some universities are offering mentorship programs and professional development opportunities specifically for faculty members from diverse backgrounds.

Another solution is to provide incentives for faculty members to stay in academia. Many talented individuals from underrepresented groups may be deterred from pursuing careers in academia due to the lack of opportunities and resources. By providing competitive salaries, benefits, and research funding, institutions can attract and retain top talent.

Additionally, institutions can also focus on creating a more inclusive and welcoming campus culture. This can be achieved by promoting diversity and inclusion initiatives, such as cultural events and diversity training programs, and by providing resources and support for students from diverse backgrounds.

In conclusion, the demographic shift in the United States is a significant challenge for higher education, but it also presents an opportunity for institutions to rethink their approach to faculty diversity. By implementing targeted recruitment and hiring practices, providing incentives for faculty members to stay in academia, and creating a more inclusive campus culture, institutions can ensure that their faculties are better equipped to teach and support a diverse student body.

Chiefs at the parent company of the Independent almost doubled their take-home pay last year as plans were being put in motion to cut jobs and shut the newspaper titles. Evgeny Lebedev's Independent titles managed to reduce pre-tax losses from £8.5m to £6.9m in the year to 27 September 2015, according to the latest and last full year accounts for the now-defunct newspapers. At a "trading" level, excluding items such as interest repayments and redundancy costs, the Independent and Independent on Sunday lost just £3.74m last year. Despite being within touching distance of breaking even, the print titles were closed in March as the Lededev's sold off stablemate the i and pursued a digital-only future for the Independent. Accounts for Lebedev Holdings, the company controlled by Evgeny Lebedev and runs the Independent, the London Evening Standard and TV station London Live, shows that despite the impending closure directors nevertheless enjoyed a bumper year. The accounts, which were filed at Companies House, reveal that the total remuneration for the top five directors at Lebedev Holdings increased by 84% to £1.4 million in the year to September 2015. This is despite the company's financial struggles and the impending closure of the Independent and Independent on Sunday print titles.

The highest-paid director, who is not named in the accounts, received a total remuneration package worth £442,000, which is a significant increase from the £240,000 they received in the previous year. The next highest-paid director received £334,000, followed by a further three directors who each received remuneration packages worth between £200,000 and £250,000.

The accounts also reveal that the company's administrative expenses increased by 15% to £10.4 million in the year to September 2015, despite the company's efforts to reduce costs. The company's editorial costs decreased by 12% to £4.4 million, but this was offset by an increase in sales and marketing expenses.

The decision to close the Independent and Independent on Sunday print titles was met with widespread criticism from journalists, readers, and politicians. The move was seen as a blow to the UK's independent media landscape and a further example of the challenges facing the print industry.

Lebedev Holdings has since sold the i newspaper to Johnston Press and has announced plans to continue the Independent as a digital-only publication. The company has also launched a new TV station, London Live, which is available on Sky and Freeview.

In a statement, a spokesperson for Lebedev Holdings said: "The company's financial results for the year to September 2015 show that we made significant progress in reducing our losses and improving our financial position. However, we also faced significant challenges in the print industry and were forced to take the difficult decision to close the Independent and Independent on Sunday print titles.

"We are committed to continuing the Independent as a digital-only publication and are investing in new content and technology to ensure its success. We are also excited about the launch of London Live, our new TV station, which we believe will provide a unique perspective on London and its communities."

The turmoil in Egypt was not the only factor contributing to the market's volatility. The uncertainty surrounding the Portuguese government's ability to manage the country's debt and economic woes added to the market's jitters.

Oil prices surged as a result of the geopolitical concerns, with Brent crude rising above $100 a barrel for the first time in over two years. The price increase was largely driven by the fear that the political instability in Egypt and Portugal could disrupt global oil supplies.

"The situation in Egypt is a major concern for the global economy," said David Kelly, chief global strategist at JPMorgan Asset Management. "The country is a major oil producer and any disruption to its oil exports could have significant implications for the global economy."

The international community is urging calm and calling for a peaceful resolution to the crisis in Egypt. The United States, European Union, and other international organizations have all issued statements condemning the violence and urging restraint.

The situation in Egypt is likely to remain volatile in the coming days, with many investors bracing for the worst. The global economy is highly interconnected, and any disruption to oil supplies or global trade could have far-reaching consequences.

In the meantime, investors are likely to remain cautious, with many seeking safe-haven assets such as gold and government bonds. The market's reaction to the events in Egypt and Portugal serves as a stark reminder of the interconnectedness of the global economy and the potential for even seemingly isolated events to have far-reaching consequences.

Two celestial events will take place on Friday night: a lunar eclipse and the passing of a comet. While both sound significant, neither will be much of a spectacle for the casual skygazer. The eclipse will be a penumbral lunar eclipse, meaning that only a portion of Earth's shadow will cover the moon. Unlike a total lunar eclipse, where the entire moon takes on a reddish color from being engulfed by the Earth's shadow, the moon will appear only slightly darker than usual during Friday's eclipse. However, astronomers and space enthusiasts will still be excited about the event, as it marks the 12th penumbral lunar eclipse in the past 20 years and the 3rd in the past 12 months. This frequency is relatively rare, making it a unique opportunity for scientists to study the Earth's atmosphere and its effects on the lunar surface.

On the other hand, the passing of the comet will be a more distant and less visible event. Comet C/2023 K1, also known as the "K1 Comet," will make its closest approach to Earth at a distance of approximately 1.5 astronomical units (AU). For perspective, the average distance between the Earth and the Sun is about 1 AU. The comet's small size and distant approach will make it difficult to spot with the naked eye, and even with binoculars, it will appear as a faint, fuzzy patch in the sky.

Despite the lack of visual spectacle, the K1 Comet is still significant because it's a new discovery and provides scientists with a chance to study the composition and behavior of a fresh comet. Comets are believed to be remnants from the formation of the solar system, and studying them can offer insights into the early history of our cosmic neighborhood.

Q. Google Maps gives the mileage between places based on driving directions on the available highways, but is there a way to calculate the distance between two towns "as the crow flies"? A. The driving directions that Google offers between locations do factor in the available roads, as well as traffic conditions, detours and other situations that may take you out of your way. However, if you're looking for a more direct and precise measurement of distance between two towns, Google Maps also provides an option to calculate the "as the crow flies" distance, also known as the straight-line distance or great-circle distance. This method calculates the distance between two points on the surface of the Earth, assuming a straight line, without considering the actual roads or highways.

To access this feature, users can simply click on the "Search" bar on Google Maps and enter the names of the two towns. Once the map loads, click on the "Directions" button and select the "Get Directions" option. On the resulting page, click on the "Options" menu and toggle the "Avoid Highways" option to "Off". This will allow Google Maps to provide the most direct route between the two locations, which is often the shortest distance between the two points.

The "as the crow flies" distance can be found on the top-right corner of the Google Maps page, under the "Distance" heading. This distance is usually significantly shorter than the driving distance, as it doesn't take into account the curves and bends of the roads. For example, the driving distance between New York City and Los Angeles is approximately 2,796 miles, while the "as the crow flies" distance is around 2,469 miles.

It's worth noting that the "as the crow flies" distance is not always the most practical or efficient way to travel between two locations. Roads and highways are designed to accommodate traffic and other factors, which can affect the overall journey time and safety. However, for purposes of planning and estimating distances, the "as the crow flies" method can be a useful tool for users.

Q. I have hundreds of TIFF-formatted photos. Is there an efficient way to convert these photos to JPG all at once? A. The age-old problem of managing digital photo collections! If you're looking for a way to convert your hundreds of TIFF-formatted photos to JPG, you're in luck. There are several efficient methods to do so, and we'll explore a few options in this article.

One of the simplest ways to convert TIFFs to JPGs is to use a dedicated image converter software. There are many options available, both free and paid, that can handle batch conversions with ease. Some popular choices include:

* IrfanView: A free image viewer and converter that supports batch processing and has a wide range of output formats, including JPG.
* XnConvert: A free and open-source image converter that can handle large batches of files and supports a wide range of output formats.
* Convertio: A free online image converter that allows you to upload your files and convert them to various formats, including JPG.

Another option is to use the built-in image converter in your operating system. For example, on Windows, you can use the "Windows Photo Viewer" to convert TIFFs to JPGs. Simply select the TIFF files you want to convert, right-click on them, and choose "Open with" > "Windows Photo Viewer". Then, click on "File" > "Save As" and select "JPEG" as the output format.

If you're using a Mac, you can use the "Preview" app to convert TIFFs to JPGs. Simply select the TIFF files you want to convert, open them in Preview, and then click on "File" > "Export" and select "JPEG" as the output format.

Regardless of which method you choose, it's essential to consider the quality of the output images. TIFFs are known for their high-quality, lossless compression, while JPGs are compressed and can lose some of their detail. If you're looking to preserve the highest level of detail, you may want to consider converting your TIFFs to a lossless format like PNG instead.

In addition to using software or built-in converters, you can also use command-line tools to convert your TIFFs to JPGs. For example, you can use the "tiff2jpg" command-line tool, which is part of the ImageMagick package. This tool allows you to convert TIFFs to JPGs using a simple command-line interface.

In conclusion, converting your TIFF-formatted photos to JPGs is a relatively straightforward process. Whether you choose to use dedicated software, built-in converters, or command-line tools, there are many efficient methods available to help you manage your digital photo collections. By following these tips, you can easily convert your TIFFs to JPGs and free up storage space on your devices.

Q. I see there's yet another Windows 10 update out now. I get notifications about patches all the time, so how do I know when this notice is for a system upgrade? Can I tell if it already installed itself? Understanding Windows 10 Updates: How to Know When to Upgrade and How to Check

For Windows 10 users, it's common to receive notifications about patches and updates on a regular basis. While these updates are designed to improve system security and performance, it's essential to know how to differentiate between a patch and a system upgrade. In this article, we'll explore how to identify when a Windows 10 update is a system upgrade and how to check if it's already installed.

Identifying System Upgrades

When a Windows 10 update is released, it's typically categorized into two types: patches and feature updates. Patches are designed to fix specific issues, such as security vulnerabilities or bugs, and are usually installed automatically. Feature updates, on the other hand, bring new features, improvements, and changes to the operating system.

To identify whether an update is a system upgrade, look for the following:

* The update description will mention new features, improvements, or changes to the operating system.
* The update will require a restart to complete the installation.
* The update will be labeled as a "Feature Update" or "Quality Update" in the Windows Update settings.

Checking for Installed Updates

To check if a system upgrade has already been installed on your Windows 10 device, follow these steps:

1. Press the Windows key + I to open the Settings app.
2. Click on Update & Security.
3. Click on Windows Update.
4. Click on the "Update history" button.
5. Look for the update you're interested in and check the "Installed on" date to see if it's been installed.

Alternatively, you can also check for installed updates by using the Windows Update Troubleshooter tool. This tool can help identify and fix issues with Windows Update, including missing or failed updates.

Tips for Managing Windows 10 Updates

To ensure your Windows 10 device stays up-to-date and secure, follow these tips:

* Enable automatic updates to ensure your device receives the latest patches and feature updates.
* Schedule updates during a time that works best for you, such as during a reboot or when you're not using your device.
* Monitor your update history to ensure that all updates have been installed successfully.
* Consider using a third-party update tool, such as the Windows Update Troubleshooter, to identify and fix issues with Windows Update.

In conclusion, understanding Windows 10 updates is crucial for maintaining a secure and performing device. By knowing how to identify system upgrades and checking for installed updates, you can ensure your device stays up-to-date and running smoothly. Remember to enable automatic updates, schedule updates during a convenient time, and monitor your update history to keep your Windows 10 device running at its best.

Despite these efforts, the giant panda population is still vulnerable to threats such as climate change, disease, and human-panda conflict. Climate change is altering the pandas' food supply and habitat, making it harder for them to survive. Disease is also a major concern, as the pandas are susceptible to diseases such as distemper and pneumonia.

To address these challenges, conservationists are working closely with local communities to develop sustainable livelihoods that do not harm the pandas or their habitats. Genetic analysis is also being used to identify the genetic makeup of the pandas and develop breeding programs that prioritize genetic diversity.

Overall, while the giant panda's conservation success story is a testament to the power of government and community efforts, it is clear that there is still much work to be done to ensure the long-term survival of this iconic species.

NEW DELHI -- Climate change and rising sea levels eventually may wipe out one of the world's last and largest tiger strongholds, scientists warned in a new study. The cats are among nearly 500,000 land species whose survival is now in question because of threats to their natural habitats, according to a report on Monday by the United Nations. The Sundarbans, 4,000 square miles of marshy land in Bangladesh and India, hosts the world's largest mangrove forest and a rich ecosystem supporting several hundred animal species, including the endangered Bengal tiger. The report, titled "IPBES Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services," highlights the alarming rate at which species are disappearing due to human activities such as deforestation, pollution, and climate change. The study found that one in eight species of land animals, including the Bengal tiger, are at risk of extinction.

The Sundarbans, a unique and fragile ecosystem, is home to not only the Bengal tiger but also other endangered species such as the Ganges River dolphin and the estuarine crocodile. The region's mangrove forests, which cover over 10% of the world's total mangrove area, provide vital shelter and food for these species.

However, the Sundarbans is also vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including rising sea levels and increased cyclone frequency. The region is already experiencing more frequent and intense flooding, which is threatening the habitat and livelihoods of the people who live there.

The UN report warns that the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services has severe consequences for human well-being, including the loss of pollination, pest control, and climate regulation. The report also highlights the economic costs of biodiversity loss, estimating that it could cost the global economy up to 20% of its annual GDP by 2050.

Conservation efforts are underway to protect the Sundarbans and its inhabitants. The Indian government has established several protected areas and conservation programs, while the Bangladesh government is working to restore degraded habitats and reduce pollution.

However, more needs to be done to address the scale and urgency of the crisis. The report calls for immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, protect and restore natural habitats, and address the root causes of biodiversity loss.

"The IPBES report is a wake-up call for all of us," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a leading conservation biologist. "We need to take immediate action to protect the natural world, not just for the sake of the animals and plants, but for our own survival."

The report's findings are a stark reminder of the urgent need for global cooperation and action to address the biodiversity crisis. As the world's largest tiger stronghold faces the threat of extinction, it is imperative that we take immediate action to protect this vital ecosystem and the species that call it home.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Technology companies rarely make money before they go public. Twitter was unprofitable when it listed on the stock market. So were Snap, Spotify and SurveyMonkey. But a growing number of tech startups are bucking this trend, achieving profitability before going public. This shift is being driven by a combination of factors, including the increasing importance of cash flow in the eyes of investors, the rise of subscription-based business models, and the need for companies to demonstrate their financial stability before listing on the stock market.

One of the most notable examples of a profitable tech startup is Zoom Video Communications, the video conferencing platform that went public in April 2019. Zoom reported a net income of $7.6 million in 2018, on revenues of $330 million, and has continued to grow its profitability since its IPO. The company's ability to generate cash has been a major factor in its success, allowing it to invest in new products and services while also returning value to its shareholders.

Another example is Slack Technologies, the workplace communication platform that went public in June 2019. Slack reported a net loss of $138 million in 2018, but its revenue grew by 50% to $400 million. The company's profitability has been driven by its subscription-based model, which generates significant recurring revenue. Slack's ability to demonstrate its financial stability before going public helped it to attract a strong reception from investors, and its stock has performed well since its IPO.

The trend towards profitability before going public is not limited to these two companies. Other successful tech startups, such as DocuSign and Atlassian, have also achieved profitability before listing on the stock market. DocuSign, the electronic signature platform, reported a net income of $21.5 million in 2018, on revenues of $591 million. Atlassian, the software development platform, reported a net income of $246 million in 2018, on revenues of $1.2 billion.

The shift towards profitability before going public is likely to continue, as investors become increasingly demanding of financial discipline from the companies they invest in. This trend is likely to benefit companies that are able to demonstrate their ability to generate cash and grow their profitability over time. For investors, it means that they will have more confidence in the financial stability of the companies they invest in, and will be more likely to support them over the long term.

Facebook will roll out a new set of tools aimed at making it easier for users to make informed choices about their privacy in response to sweeping new European privacy laws, according to the company's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg. "We're rolling out a new privacy centre globally that will put the core privacy settings for Facebook in one place and make it much easier for people to manage their data," Sandberg said at a Facebook event in Brussels on Tuesday. She said that the creation of a "privacy centre" was prompted by the requirements of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), an EU regulation that seeks to give Europeans more control over their information and how companies use it. The new privacy centre will be available globally, not just in the European Union, and will provide users with a single location to manage their privacy settings, including options to control who can see their posts, share their location, and access their account information. Sandberg emphasized that the goal of the new centre is to empower users to make informed decisions about their privacy, rather than simply presenting them with a complex array of options.

"We want to make it easy for people to understand what data we're collecting, why we're collecting it, and how we're using it," Sandberg said. "We want to give people the tools they need to make informed choices about their privacy, and to feel confident that they're in control of their data."

The new privacy centre is just one of the measures that Facebook is taking to comply with the GDPR, which comes into effect on May 25. The regulation requires companies to provide users with clear and transparent information about how their data is being used, and to obtain their explicit consent before collecting or sharing their personal information.

In addition to the privacy centre, Facebook is also updating its data policy to provide users with more information about how their data is being used. The company is also introducing new features to help users delete or correct their personal data, and to provide them with more control over how their data is shared with third-party apps.

The changes are part of a broader effort by Facebook to improve transparency and accountability around data privacy. The company has faced criticism in recent years over its handling of user data, including the Cambridge Analytica scandal, in which millions of Facebook users' personal information was harvested and used for political advertising.

Sandberg acknowledged that Facebook still has work to do to regain the trust of its users, but she emphasized that the company is committed to protecting their privacy and providing them with the tools they need to make informed decisions.

"We're committed to being transparent about how we use data, and to giving people the tools they need to control their data," Sandberg said. "We're committed to making sure that our users feel confident that their data is safe with us."

The new privacy centre is expected to roll out globally in the coming weeks, and will be available to all Facebook users, regardless of their location.

Q. I'm deleting Yahoo and my Flickr account. In regards to Flickr, I still have most of the original images on my computer, but need to retrieve a handful of photos I can't find on my hard drive. Thomas Cook customers in Tunisia have been involved in a standoff with a hotel owner who barricaded holidaymakers inside a resort due to fears that the struggling holiday firm would not be able to pay bills. Guests at the Orangers hotel in the coastal town of Hammamet spoke of being locked inside their resort on Saturday until a 6,000 Tunisian dinar (£1,680) fee was paid before they were allowed to leave for their flight, or even to visit a shop. Those buses that arrived to transport holidaymakers to the airport at Enfidha were turned away by security, Orangers guests told the Guardian. Thomas Cook customers Maddie Clamp, 26, and her boyfriend, Shaun Holmes, 30, from Derby described how they had been locked within their holiday complex as management, apparently wrong-footed by the news of the travel giant's financial troubles, tried to secure payment from their guests. "They wouldn't even let us out of the hotel," Holmes said. "The Thomas Cook rep said he'd contacted the chief of police [about their situation]." The standoff at the Orangers hotel in Hammamet, Tunisia, has sparked widespread concern among Thomas Cook customers, who were left feeling trapped and helpless as they awaited a resolution to the situation.

According to eyewitnesses, the hotel's management team, seemingly caught off guard by the news of Thomas Cook's financial struggles, attempted to recoup the outstanding debt by demanding a significant fee from the holidaymakers. The demand, equivalent to £1,680, was met with resistance from the guests, who felt it was unfair and unreasonable.

"It was like being held hostage," said Maddie Clamp, 26, who was on holiday with her boyfriend Shaun Holmes, 30, from Derby. "We were told we couldn't leave the hotel until the fee was paid, and even then, we were only allowed to leave for our flight or to visit a shop. It was a very stressful and unsettling experience."

The situation was further complicated by the fact that buses sent to transport the holidaymakers to the airport at Enfidha were turned away by security, leaving the guests feeling stranded and uncertain about their future travel plans.

Thomas Cook has since issued a statement apologizing for the incident and assuring customers that it is working to resolve the situation as quickly as possible. The company has also offered to provide alternative accommodation and transportation for affected customers.

In the meantime, the Tunisian authorities have launched an investigation into the matter, with local police and officials working to mediate the situation and ensure the safe and timely departure of the holidaymakers.

The standoff at the Orangers hotel has raised concerns about the impact of Thomas Cook's financial struggles on its customers, particularly those who are currently on holiday or planning to travel with the company in the coming weeks. As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen how Thomas Cook will address the issue and ensure that its customers are protected and supported during this challenging time.

Money troubles interfere with the academic performance of about one-third of all college students, and a similar number of students regularly skip buying required academic materials because of the costs, according to a survey released on Thursday. In an era of stagnant incomes and rising tuition and student debt, the burden of college costs on families and former students is well documented. The survey, conducted by the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators (NASFAA), found that 34% of students reported that financial struggles affected their academic performance, with 31% saying they had to skip buying required textbooks, software, or other materials due to the high costs.

The results of the survey highlight the growing concern about the affordability of higher education in the United States. With tuition rates continuing to rise, many students are forced to take on significant debt to finance their education. According to the NASFAA, the average student debt for the class of 2019 was over $31,000.

The financial struggles faced by college students can have long-term consequences, including delayed graduation, reduced career opportunities, and increased stress levels. The survey found that 45% of students reported feeling stressed about their financial situation, with 21% saying they felt anxious or overwhelmed.

The NASFAA survey also found that financial struggles were more common among certain groups of students. For example, 43% of students from low-income families reported that financial struggles affected their academic performance, compared to 25% of students from higher-income families. Similarly, 36% of students who were the first in their family to attend college reported skipping required academic materials due to cost, compared to 23% of students whose parents had attended college.

The survey's findings have prompted calls for policymakers to address the affordability crisis in higher education. "These results are a wake-up call for policymakers and educators to take action to make college more affordable and accessible," said Justin Draeger, president of NASFAA. "We need to work together to find solutions that benefit students and families, not just the institutions and investors."

Some potential solutions include increasing funding for need-based financial aid, implementing more affordable textbook options, and providing resources to help students manage their debt. The NASFAA survey also found that many students are unaware of the financial aid options available to them, highlighting the need for greater awareness and education about the financial aid process.

As the cost of higher education continues to rise, it is clear that something must be done to address the financial struggles faced by college students. The NASFAA survey is a stark reminder of the need for policymakers, educators, and institutions to work together to make college more affordable and accessible for all students.

Q My husband and I are considering severing our joint tenancy and becoming tenants in common. We would be doing this to protect our children's inheritance. I believe that by doing this we can give our shares of the property to our daughters, but remain in it should either of us die. Title: Protecting Inheritance: The Benefits of Tenants in Common

As a married couple, John and Sarah have been considering ways to protect their children's inheritance. One option they are exploring is converting their joint tenancy to a tenancy in common. This move would allow them to divide their property shares among their daughters, while still retaining the right to occupy the property until their passing.

Under a joint tenancy, the property is automatically inherited by the surviving joint tenant(s) upon the death of one of the owners. This means that if one partner dies, the other partner would automatically inherit the entire property, regardless of what the deceased partner's will or estate plan may have specified. By converting to a tenancy in common, John and Sarah can avoid this automatic inheritance and instead leave their shares of the property to their daughters.

There are several benefits to converting to a tenancy in common. For one, it allows the couple to divide their property shares among multiple beneficiaries, rather than just one. This can be particularly useful for couples with multiple children, as it allows each child to inherit a portion of the property. Additionally, a tenancy in common can provide greater flexibility in terms of inheritance, as the couple can specify exactly how they want their property shares to be distributed upon their passing.

Another advantage of a tenancy in common is that it can help to avoid disputes between beneficiaries. When a property is inherited under a joint tenancy, the surviving joint tenant(s) may have significant control over the property, which can lead to disputes between the beneficiaries. By converting to a tenancy in common, John and Sarah can avoid this potential source of conflict and ensure that their daughters inherit their shares of the property in a peaceful and orderly manner.

To convert their joint tenancy to a tenancy in common, John and Sarah will need to execute a new deed that reflects their changed ownership status. This deed will need to be signed by both parties and recorded with the local government. It's also a good idea for the couple to consult with an attorney to ensure that their new deed complies with all applicable laws and regulations.

In conclusion, converting a joint tenancy to a tenancy in common can be a valuable way for couples to protect their children's inheritance and ensure that their property is distributed according to their wishes. By doing so, John and Sarah can provide for their daughters' financial security and peace of mind, while also avoiding potential disputes and complications that may arise from a joint tenancy.

Uber's European operation has been fined £385,000 for a data breach that affected almost 3 million British users, the Information Commissioner's Office has announced. In November 2016, attackers obtained credentials to access Uber's cloud servers and downloaded 16 large files, including the records of 35 million users worldwide. The records included passengers' full names, phone numbers, email addresses, and the location where they had signed up. Drivers were also affected, with 3.7 million, including 82,000 from the UK, having their weekly pay, trip summaries and, in a small number of cases, driver's licence numbers accessed. The ICO said the breach was caused by inadequate information security, and was compounded by Uber US's decision to not disclose the attack, instead complying with the hackers' demands to pay $100,000 as a "bug bounty". The fine, which is the largest ever imposed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), is a result of Uber's failure to protect the personal data of its users and drivers. The ICO investigation found that Uber's inadequate security measures allowed the attackers to gain unauthorized access to its cloud servers, resulting in the theft of sensitive information.

"This was not only a serious breach of people's privacy, but it was also caused by Uber's failure to follow basic data security practices," said Elizabeth Denham, the UK's Information Commissioner. "We took enforcement action because Uber failed to act quickly to inform those affected and failed to demonstrate any real understanding of the impact of the breach on the individuals affected."

The ICO's investigation also found that Uber US's decision to pay the hackers $100,000, rather than reporting the breach to the authorities, was a major factor in the fine. "This was a deliberate attempt to cover up the breach, and it's unacceptable," said Denham.

The fine is a significant blow to Uber's reputation, which has already been tarnished by a series of scandals and controversies in recent years. The company has faced criticism over its handling of sexual harassment allegations, its treatment of drivers, and its use of fake riders to spy on its competitors.

In a statement, Uber said it takes the security and privacy of its users' data very seriously, and it is working to improve its security measures. "We have taken concrete steps to improve the security of our systems, including implementing additional security measures and conducting regular security audits," said the company.

The fine is the latest in a series of penalties imposed on companies for data breaches. In recent years, the ICO has fined companies such as Facebook, Twitter, and Google for failing to protect their users' data.

The incident highlights the importance of companies taking robust measures to protect their users' data, and the need for greater transparency and accountability in the event of a breach. As the use of personal data becomes increasingly widespread, it is essential that companies take their responsibilities seriously and prioritize the privacy and security of their users' data.

Orr's argument is that by focusing solely on the perceived injustices and inequalities within the wealthy elite, we are neglecting the broader social and economic issues that affect the majority of the population. She suggests that this approach can actually reinforce the existing social hierarchies, rather than challenging them.

This perspective is supported by research in social psychology, which has shown that when people are faced with criticism or ridicule, they often respond by becoming more defensive and isolated. This can lead to a sense of group cohesion and loyalty among the targeted group, as they rally together to defend themselves against perceived attacks.

Moreover, Orr argues that by constantly emphasizing the differences between the rich and the poor, we are perpetuating a narrative that reinforces class divisions and social segregation. This can lead to a lack of understanding and empathy between different social classes, making it more difficult to address the underlying issues that contribute to inequality.

However, not everyone agrees with Orr's assessment. Some argue that criticizing the wealthy and privileged is a necessary step in highlighting the injustices and inequalities that exist in society. They argue that by shining a light on the excesses and inequalities of the elite, we can create a sense of moral outrage and pressure for change.

This debate highlights the complex and nuanced nature of social and economic issues. While it is important to acknowledge the challenges and inequalities faced by the majority of the population, it is also important to recognize the potential unintended consequences of our actions. By engaging in a more nuanced and thoughtful discussion about these issues, we can work towards creating a more just and equitable society for all.

In contrast, discounters Aldi and Lidl continue to see double-digit growth, with sales up 11.5% and 13.8% respectively, taking their combined market share to a new high of 10.5%. The decline in the UK grocery market has been attributed to a combination of factors, including the ongoing cost-of-living crisis, changing consumer behavior, and intense competition. Asda's poor performance has been particularly concerning, with its sales decline being the largest seen in the market.

The data from Kantar Worldpanel shows that Asda's struggles have been driven by a decline in sales across all categories, including food, non-food, and online shopping. The supermarket chain has been trying to recover from a series of setbacks, including a failed attempt to revamp its brand and a struggle to compete with the discounters.

Tesco, on the other hand, has managed to maintain a relatively stable performance, with sales down by 1.3%. The supermarket chain has been focusing on improving its online shopping service and expanding its range of premium products, which has helped to attract more affluent customers.

Aldi and Lidl, the discounters, continue to thrive in the market, with sales up by 11.5% and 13.8% respectively. Their combined market share has reached a new high of 10.5%, making them a significant force in the UK grocery market. The discounters' success has been driven by their ability to offer low prices and a limited range of products, which appeals to price-conscious consumers.

The decline in the UK grocery market is likely to continue in the coming months, as consumers become increasingly cautious with their spending. However, the supermarkets are expected to respond by investing in price promotions and improving their services to attract more customers.

In response to the decline, Asda has announced plans to reduce its prices and improve its supply chain to become more competitive. Tesco has also pledged to continue investing in its online shopping service and premium products to attract more customers.

The UK grocery market is expected to remain highly competitive in the coming years, with the discounters continuing to pose a threat to the traditional supermarkets. However, the supermarkets are likely to adapt and respond to the changing market conditions, ensuring that consumers continue to have a wide range of options when it comes to buying their groceries.

The trial, which is set to begin in the coming weeks, marks a significant milestone for Waymo, as it looks to further test the capabilities of its autonomous vehicles in real-world scenarios. By giving hundreds of residents in Phoenix access to its fleet of 600 self-driving minivans, Waymo hopes to gather valuable feedback and insights on how to improve its technology.

"We're excited to bring this trial to Phoenix and to work with the community to help us refine our self-driving technology," said Krafcik. "This trial will allow us to test our vehicles in a variety of scenarios and conditions, and to gather feedback from a diverse group of participants."

The trial is open to residents of Phoenix who are at least 18 years old and have a valid driver's license. Participants will be required to sign a waiver and agree to provide feedback on their experiences with the self-driving vehicles.

In addition to providing feedback, participants will also be given access to a dedicated app that will allow them to request rides and track the location of the vehicles. The app will also provide participants with information on the status of their ride, including the estimated arrival time and any delays.

Waymo's trial in Phoenix is the latest in a series of autonomous vehicle tests and trials that the company has conducted in recent years. In 2018, the company launched a self-driving taxi service in Phoenix, which allowed passengers to hail rides using the company's app. The service was a success, with thousands of passengers using the service to get around the city.

The trial is also a significant milestone for the city of Phoenix, which has been working to become a hub for autonomous vehicle testing and development. The city has invested heavily in infrastructure and has partnered with several companies, including Waymo, to support the growth of the autonomous vehicle industry.

"This trial is a great opportunity for Phoenix to showcase its commitment to innovation and technology," said Phoenix Mayor Kate Gallego. "We're excited to see the benefits that autonomous vehicles can bring to our city and to our residents, and we're proud to be working with Waymo to make that a reality."

The trial is expected to last for several months, during which time Waymo will be gathering data and feedback from participants. The company will use this information to refine its technology and to improve the overall experience for passengers.

In the long term, Waymo hopes to expand its autonomous vehicle service to other cities and to offer a range of services, including ride-hailing and delivery. The company is also exploring the use of its technology in other areas, such as public transportation and logistics.

As the trial gets underway, Waymo is urging residents of Phoenix to apply to participate and to help shape the future of autonomous vehicles. David Shariatmadari has a point when he characterises resistance against neologisms such as "I was like…" as inconsistent and futile (Love Island is a lesson in how language, like, evolves, 22 June). However, a more worrying point, which he might have addressed, is the way in which – no doubt due to the same processes that lead to the introduction of such terms – single words or phrases come to dominate language, killing off any opposition, and ultimately impoverishing it; to the extent that, for instance, many people nowadays seem to have only a single superlative at their disposal, resulting in such things as a poster that hangs in my GP's surgery, asking: "Have you had great care today?" Jim Grozier Brighton, East Sussex • Anyone who feels upset by the overuse of "like" might turn to the American poet AE Stallings, who takes it for the title of her 2018 collection. The proliferation of colloquialisms and slang in modern language is a phenomenon that has been observed and debated by linguists and language enthusiasts alike. While some argue that the evolution of language is a natural and necessary process, others lament the loss of precision and nuance that can result from the widespread adoption of informal language.

In the case of "I was like...", it is true that the phrase has become a staple of contemporary language, particularly among younger generations. However, as Shariatmadari notes, resistance to such neologisms is often futile, as language is constantly adapting to the needs and preferences of its users.

But the issue goes beyond simply the use of a particular phrase or word. The dominance of single words or phrases can have a profound impact on the way we communicate, ultimately leading to a homogenization of language that can be detrimental to its richness and diversity.

The example cited by Jim Grozier, the poster in his GP's surgery asking "Have you had great care today?", is a telling one. The use of the superlative "great" in this context is a perfect illustration of how language can become impoverished when we rely too heavily on a single word or phrase. The subtleties and nuances of language are lost when we are unable to convey complex emotions and ideas through a range of vocabulary and expression.

Furthermore, the dominance of certain words or phrases can also have a profound impact on the way we think and express ourselves. When we rely too heavily on a single way of communicating, we can become trapped in a particular mindset or perspective, limiting our ability to explore new ideas and perspectives.

In conclusion, while the evolution of language is a natural and necessary process, it is essential that we remain vigilant and aware of the impact that the dominance of certain words or phrases can have on the way we communicate and think. By embracing the diversity and complexity of language, we can ensure that our communication remains rich, nuanced, and expressive, and that our language continues to evolve in a way that is both natural and enriching.

He emphasized that the central bank's actions are aimed at achieving a sustainable economic recovery, rather than to gain a competitive advantage over other countries.

"We are committed to using all available tools to achieve our inflation target and promote sustainable economic growth," he said.

The Bank of Japan has been implementing an aggressive monetary policy in recent years, including negative interest rates and massive asset purchases. The central bank has also been experimenting with unconventional measures, such as yield curve control, to stimulate the economy.

Kuroda's comments were seen as a response to criticism from some quarters that Japan's monetary policy is designed to weaken the yen and boost exports. However, the central bank governor insisted that the bank's actions are aimed at achieving a sustainable economic recovery, rather than to manipulate the currency.

The Japanese government has also been implementing fiscal stimulus measures to boost the economy. In January, the government announced a package of measures worth around $120 billion, including increased spending on infrastructure and social welfare programs.

Despite the challenges facing the Japanese economy, Kuroda remains confident that the country can achieve its economic goals. "We are committed to achieving our inflation target and promoting sustainable economic growth," he said. "We will continue to use all available tools to achieve this goal."

The Bank of Japan's next policy meeting is scheduled for March, and market analysts are expecting the central bank to maintain its current monetary policy stance. However, some analysts are predicting that the bank may consider further easing measures if the economy continues to struggle.

Overall, the Bank of Japan's governor remains committed to achieving a sustainable economic recovery, and is confident that the country can achieve its economic goals. However, the challenges facing the Japanese economy are significant, and the country will need to continue to implement effective policies to support its economic growth.

BP has agreed to buy US shale oil and gasfields from the Anglo-Australian miner BHP for $10.5bn (£8bn), in the UK firm's biggest acquisition in nearly two decades. Bob Dudley, BP's chief executive, lauded the deal as transformational and industry watchers said the move significantly beefed up the company's US shale presence, which was small compared to peers. The acquisition will boost BP's US oil and gas production by nearly a fifth and marks a new period of growth for the company, which is emerging after years under the $65bn burden of the Deepwater Horizon disaster. The deal, which is expected to close in the second half of 2023, will see BP acquire BHP's shale oil and gas assets in the Permian Basin, the Eagle Ford Shale, and the Haynesville Shale, among others. The acquisition is expected to add around 200,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to BP's production, making it one of the largest transactions in the US shale industry in recent years.

Industry analysts say the deal is a significant coup for BP, which has been looking to expand its presence in the US shale market for some time. "This acquisition is a major win for BP," said Neil Beveridge, an energy analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. "It gives them a much stronger foothold in the US shale market and positions them well for future growth."

The acquisition is also seen as a strategic move by BP to diversify its energy mix and reduce its reliance on declining oil fields. The company has been shifting its focus towards lower-carbon energy sources, such as natural gas and renewable energy, and the US shale assets will help it achieve this goal.

The deal is also expected to create jobs and stimulate economic growth in the regions where the assets are located. "This acquisition will create new opportunities for jobs and economic growth in the communities where we operate," said Dudley. "We are committed to being a responsible and sustainable energy company and this deal is a key part of that."

The acquisition is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to close in the second half of 2023. Once completed, the deal will be one of the largest in BP's history, and marks a significant turning point for the company as it looks to the future.

In a statement, BHP said it was pleased to have reached an agreement with BP and looked forward to working with the company to ensure a smooth transition. "This transaction is a great outcome for BHP and its shareholders," said BHP's CEO, Mike Henry. "It allows us to focus on our core copper and iron ore business and continue to deliver value to our shareholders."

The deal is the latest in a series of significant transactions in the US shale industry in recent years. Last year, ExxonMobil acquired a stake in the Permian Basin from Russian state-owned oil company Rosneft, while Chevron acquired a stake in the Eagle Ford Shale from Occidental Petroleum.

On the rocky cliffs of the Himalayas, the path to snow leopard conservation is paved in feces. Their population decimated by poaching and habitat destruction, only about 4,000 of the endangered cats remain in the wild, according to the World Wildlife Fund. Conflicts with mountain farmers and pastoral herders also contribute to their dwindling numbers. Conservation Efforts Take a Unique Turn

To combat the decline of snow leopards, conservationists are turning to an unlikely ally: the cat's own waste. The feces of snow leopards, also known as scat, holds valuable information about the species' diet, habitat, and behavior. By analyzing the scat, researchers can gain insights into the cats' ecological role and identify areas where conservation efforts can be most effective.

The Himalayan Snow Leopard Conservation Program, a joint initiative between the World Wildlife Fund and the Government of Nepal, is at the forefront of this innovative approach. The program's researchers collect scat samples from the wild and transport them to a laboratory in Kathmandu for analysis.

"Scat analysis is a game-changer for snow leopard conservation," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a leading researcher on the project. "It allows us to understand the cat's diet and habitat preferences, which informs our conservation strategies. For example, if we find that the snow leopards are primarily feeding on a certain species of rodent, we can target conservation efforts to protect that species and its habitat."

The program's findings have already led to significant changes in conservation policies. For instance, the Nepalese government has established protected areas and corridors to connect fragmented habitats, allowing snow leopards to roam freely and safely. The program has also worked with local communities to develop sustainable livelihoods, such as ecotourism and sustainable agriculture, which reduce the conflict between humans and snow leopards.

However, despite these successes, the challenges facing snow leopard conservation remain significant. Habitat destruction and fragmentation continue to be major threats, as do conflicts with local communities. The program is working to address these issues through a combination of education, outreach, and community engagement.

"We recognize that snow leopard conservation is not just about protecting the cat itself, but also about the communities that live alongside them," said Dr. Rodriguez. "We're working to build trust and partnerships with local communities, and to develop solutions that benefit both humans and snow leopards."

As the Himalayan Snow Leopard Conservation Program continues to make strides in the field, the path to snow leopard conservation is indeed paved in feces – but it's a crucial step towards ensuring the long-term survival of this majestic species.

MPs are to investigate how many occupational pension schemes are at risk of failing, amid inquiries into the collapse of BHS and the debate over the future of the £15bn British Steel pension fund. The Commons work and pensions select committee, which is already investigating the £571m deficit at BHS scheme, said on Friday night it would launch a wide ranging inquiry into the problem, probably starting in the autumn. Workers' occupational pensions have been forced centre stage in recent months by BHS's collapse and by Tata Steel's potential sale of its UK business. Almost 13,000 current and former BHS employees who were under retirement age when the company went into administration in March may face a 10% cut to their pensions as a result. The inquiry comes as concerns grow about the financial health of many occupational pension schemes, which are funded by employers and provide a guaranteed income to employees in retirement. According to the Pensions Regulator, there are over 5,000 occupational pension schemes in the UK, with a combined deficit of around £100 billion.

The committee's chair, Frank Field, said the inquiry would examine the reasons behind the growing number of schemes at risk of failing, and what can be done to prevent further collapses. "We need to get to the bottom of why so many occupational pension schemes are struggling, and what can be done to protect the interests of workers who have been promised a certain level of income in retirement," Field said.

The committee will also investigate the role of pension fund managers and trustees in managing schemes, as well as the impact of changes to the pension landscape, such as the introduction of auto-enrolment and the increase in the state pension age.

The inquiry is expected to hear evidence from a range of stakeholders, including pension fund managers, trustees, and industry experts. The committee will also examine the experiences of workers who have been affected by pension scheme failures, and the support available to them.

The news of the inquiry comes as workers at British Steel are facing uncertainty over the future of their pension scheme. The £15 billion fund, which is one of the largest in the UK, is under review as part of Tata Steel's potential sale of its UK business. The fund is currently facing a deficit of around £1 billion, and workers are concerned about the potential impact on their retirement plans.

The situation is also being closely watched by employees of other companies that have been sold or are facing financial difficulties. The collapse of BHS has left thousands of workers facing a reduction in their pension benefits, and there are fears that other schemes could follow suit if they are not properly funded.

The inquiry is expected to provide much-needed clarity and guidance for workers and employers, and to help prevent further pension scheme failures. As the committee begins its investigation, it is clear that the future of occupational pensions in the UK is at a critical juncture, and that action is needed to protect the interests of workers and ensure that they receive the retirement income they have been promised.
