"We still have a lot of work to do to get our economy back on track," De Guindos said. "We need to continue to implement structural reforms and reduce our debt levels to ensure that we can sustain our economic growth over the long term."

The government is expected to present its 2014 budget later this month, which will include details on how it plans to achieve its economic goals.

Q. I installed ad-blocking software on my computer, but I still see advertisements on some pages, even though the site did not ask me to turn off the blocker. Why is this? A. Even when you have the software enabled, browser utilities like AdBlock or AdBlock Plus may still display less-intrusive advertisements from companies that have been approved by the independent Acceptable Ads Committee. The Acceptable Ads initiative was started by AdBlock Plus, which makes money by allowing the ads through its filters. The Acceptable Ads Committee, a non-profit organization, reviews and approves ads that meet certain criteria, such as being non-intrusive and not disrupting the user experience. These approved ads are then whitelisted, allowing them to bypass the ad-blocking software. The committee's goal is to strike a balance between user privacy and the need for websites to generate revenue through advertising.

According to the committee's guidelines, ads must meet certain standards to be considered acceptable. These include being non-animated, not taking up more than 12.5% of the screen, and not making noise or playing audio. Additionally, ads must not collect user data without explicit consent, and must not be misleading or deceptive.

Websites that want to display approved ads must apply to the Acceptable Ads Committee and meet the guidelines. The committee then reviews the ad and decides whether it meets the criteria. If approved, the ad is whitelisted, and the ad-blocking software will allow it to be displayed.

While the Acceptable Ads initiative aims to provide a compromise between ad-blocking and advertising, some users may still choose to disable the feature altogether. This is because even approved ads can be annoying or distracting, and some users may prefer a completely ad-free browsing experience.

In response to concerns about the initiative, AdBlock Plus has implemented a feature that allows users to customize their ad-blocking settings. This includes the option to disable approved ads or to only allow ads from specific websites or categories. This added control gives users more flexibility in managing their online experience.

The Acceptable Ads initiative has sparked debate among users, with some praising the compromise and others criticizing the inclusion of any ads at all. As the digital landscape continues to evolve, it will be interesting to see how ad-blocking software and advertising companies adapt to changing user preferences and regulations.

All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you're lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse. The next shower you might be able to see is known as the Lyrids. Active between April 16 and 28, the show peaks around Sunday night into Monday morning, or April 21-22. The Lyrids meteor shower is one of the oldest and most reliable annual events in the sky, with records of the shower dating back to 687 BC. It's caused by the Earth passing through the trail of debris left behind by the Comet Thatcher, which was discovered in 1861. The comet's orbit brings it close to Earth every 415 years, and its path crosses the planet's orbit, creating a trail of tiny particles that burn up in the atmosphere, producing the bright streaks of light we see as meteors.

The Lyrids are known for their bright and fast-moving meteors, with some reaching speeds of up to 45 miles per second. This means that the meteors can appear to be quite large and bright, making them a treat for astronomers and stargazers alike. The shower is also notable for its high rate of producing bright fireballs, which can be seen from great distances and are often accompanied by a loud sonic boom.

To catch a glimpse of the Lyrids, find a dark location with minimal light pollution and dress warmly, as it can get chilly while waiting for the shower to peak. Bring binoculars or a star chart to help you locate the constellations and spot the meteors. The best viewing time is usually around midnight to 4am, when the Earth is facing the direction of the comet's debris trail.

The Lyrids meteor shower is a great opportunity for people of all ages to get outside and enjoy the night sky. It's a chance to connect with nature and experience the awe-inspiring beauty of the universe. So mark your calendars for April 21-22 and get ready to witness one of the most spectacular celestial events of the year.

The additional cost would be £150, which would be added to the original quote. I was left feeling a bit annoyed but also relieved that the work would still be completed in a timely manner.

The glaziers returned a few days later and completed the installation of the remaining four windows. The safety glass was installed in the two windows that required it, and the entire job was finally finished. The total cost ended up being £550, which was £150 more than the original quote.

I'm a 26-year-old male who has landed his first proper job, but my heart sank at the dress code: smart casual. What does that actually mean? The age-old conundrum of deciphering dress code instructions! Smart casual is a term that can strike fear into the hearts of even the most fashion-conscious individuals. But fear not, dear reader, for we're here to help you navigate this sartorial minefield.

Smart casual is a dress code that's often used in professional settings, such as workplaces, restaurants, or events. It's a middle ground between formal and casual attire, requiring a balance between style and practicality. Think of it as a "business-casual" outfit with a touch of sophistication.

So, what does smart casual actually mean? Here are some general guidelines to help you get it right:

1. Avoid ripped or distressed clothing: While ripped jeans might be acceptable in a casual setting, they're not suitable for a smart casual occasion. Opt for clean, straight-leg or slim-fit jeans instead.
2. Choose a decent top: A plain white or light-colored shirt is a safe bet. Avoid low-cut or overly revealing tops, and instead opt for something with a bit of texture or interest, such as a patterned or striped design.
3. Add a blazer or cardigan: A blazer or cardigan can instantly elevate your outfit from casual to smart casual. Look for something in a neutral color that complements your shirt and pants.
4. Shoes matter: Avoid sneakers or flip-flops, and instead opt for loafers, ballet flats, or dress shoes. Make sure they're clean and polished to add a touch of sophistication.
5. Accessories are key: A simple watch, a slim belt, and a quality wallet can make a big difference in your overall look. Avoid anything too flashy or attention-seeking.
6. Pay attention to fabrics: Smart casual attire often features high-quality fabrics, such as cotton, wool, or linen. Avoid synthetic materials or anything that looks too cheap.

Some examples of smart casual outfits might include:

* A pair of dark-washed jeans with a white or light-colored button-down shirt, a blazer, and loafers.
* A skirt or dress with a pair of tights and a cardigan, paired with ballet flats or loafers.
* A pair of chinos with a polo shirt, a cardigan, and dress shoes.

Remember, the key to smart casual is to look polished and put-together without being too formal. With a little practice, you'll be a pro at deciphering dress code instructions in no time!

British consumers have been dipping further into their savings amid a squeeze from rising prices and falling real wages, figures show, as growth in personal bank deposits fell to the slowest annual rate since the height of the financial crisis. Annual growth in personal deposits with high street banks fell to 2.2% in August, in the weakest month since May 2009, according to figures published by banking trade body UK Finance. There was also about £1bn withdrawn from cash Isa accounts, with tax changes allowing up to £1,000 of interest to be earned tax free. The trade body said: "It seems households are saving a bit less each month, rather than borrowing more, as growth in personal deposits has slowed recently, alongside a slowdown in growth of consumer credit borrowing." Annual growth in credit card borrowing was at 5% in August, compared with 5.3% the previous month, while the use of personal loans and overdrafts fell by 1.6% on an annual basis, from a contraction of 1% in the year to July. The decline in personal savings is attributed to the ongoing cost-of-living crisis, which has seen households struggling to make ends meet due to rising prices and stagnant wages. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) rose by 2.1% in August, the highest level since March 2017. Economists have warned that the decline in personal savings could have long-term consequences for the economy, particularly if households are unable to build up a sufficient safety net to weather future economic shocks. "The slowdown in personal savings is a cause for concern, as it suggests that households are becoming increasingly reliant on credit to fund their spending," said Rachel Winter, an economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research. "This could lead to a vicious cycle of debt and financial instability if not addressed."

The Bank of England has also expressed concerns about the decline in personal savings, citing the need for households to build up a sufficient buffer to absorb future economic shocks. In its latest inflation report, the Bank warned that households are becoming increasingly vulnerable to financial shocks, particularly if interest rates rise or the economy enters a recession.

Despite the decline in personal savings, some experts argue that the current economic conditions are not as dire as they seem. "While it's true that households are saving less, it's also important to note that the economy is still growing, albeit slowly," said Vicky Pryce, a former chief economic advisor to the government. "Households are also becoming more cautious about their spending, which could actually help to reduce debt and improve financial stability in the long run."

In the meantime, households are being advised to review their financial priorities and build up a sufficient safety net to weather future economic shocks. "It's essential that households take steps to manage their finances effectively, including building up an emergency fund and paying off high-interest debt," said Sarah Pennells, a personal finance expert at the Money Advice Service. "By taking these steps, households can reduce their reliance on credit and improve their overall financial resilience."

The 150 artefacts on display will include golden masks, precious jewels, and intricately carved sarcophagi, offering a unique glimpse into the life and legacy of the young pharaoh who ruled ancient Egypt from around 1332 to 1323 BCE.

The treasures will be transported to the Saatchi Gallery in a specially designed, climate-controlled container to ensure their safety and preservation. The gallery, known for its innovative exhibitions and cutting-edge technology, has undergone extensive renovations to accommodate the scale and grandeur of the Tutankhamun collection.

"This exhibition is a testament to the enduring fascination with ancient Egypt and the importance of preserving our cultural heritage," he said. "We are thrilled to be sharing these treasures with the people of the UK and look forward to a successful and memorable tour."

The exhibition will be accompanied by a range of interactive displays, educational programs, and workshops, allowing visitors to delve deeper into the history and significance of the artefacts on display. Visitors will also have the opportunity to explore a recreated tomb chamber, complete with authentic Egyptian architecture and artifacts.

The Saatchi Gallery's director, Rebecca Wilson, expressed her excitement about hosting the exhibition. "We are honored to be a part of this groundbreaking project and to have the opportunity to showcase these incredible treasures to the people of the UK," she said. "The exhibition promises to be a truly immersive and unforgettable experience, and we can't wait to share it with our visitors."

It is a 100% mortgage but not, thank goodness, as we once knew them. Lloyds Bank's new Lend a Hand mortgage offers first-time buyers the chance to borrow the entire price of their new home – but with the considerable caveat that a relative has to have a lump sum worth 10% that they are willing to tie up for three years, and have it raided if you miss any payments. However, many experts still caution that the market remains challenging, particularly for those with limited financial resources.

Lloyds Bank's innovative mortgage solution is a step in the right direction, but it's crucial to recognize that it's not a panacea for the housing market's issues. The bank's move is likely to be closely watched by other lenders, and it will be interesting to see if similar products emerge in the coming months.

In conclusion, Lloyds Bank's Lend a Hand mortgage offers a unique solution for first-time buyers, but it's essential to carefully consider the terms and conditions before applying. While it may not be suitable for everyone, it could be a viable option for those with a supportive family member and a solid financial plan. As the housing market continues to evolve, it will be important to monitor the impact of innovative mortgage products like Lend a Hand and their potential to make homeownership more accessible.

The settlement also requires Musical.ly to delete all personal information it collected from children under the age of 13, as well as implement new measures to ensure that it complies with COPPA in the future.

The F.T.C. Commissioner, Rohit Chopra, praised the settlement, saying that it "sends a strong message to companies that they must prioritize the privacy and security of children's personal information." Chopra also emphasized the importance of COPPA, saying that it is "a critical tool in our efforts to protect children from the risks of online data collection and exploitation."

The settlement is the latest in a series of actions taken by the F.T.C. to protect children's privacy online. In recent years, the agency has taken enforcement actions against several companies, including Google, Facebook, and Amazon, for violating COPPA and other privacy laws.

The spokesperson also stated that the company will comply with the terms of the settlement and will work to ensure that its app is in compliance with COPPA and other privacy laws.

The settlement is a significant victory for the F.T.C. and for parents who are concerned about the privacy and safety of their children online. All the parties in the general election have adopted mental health as a key issue. But this enthusiasm is not reflected on the ground and the electorate should not be fooled. We are students and former students on the internationally renowned counselling programme at the University of East Anglia. As we navigate the complex landscape of party manifestos and campaign promises, it's easy to get swept up in the rhetoric surrounding mental health. But as students and former students of the University of East Anglia's internationally renowned counselling programme, we've seen firsthand the stark reality of mental health support on the ground.

While politicians are quick to tout their commitment to mental health, the truth is that many of these promises are vague and lack concrete action. We've witnessed students struggling to access counselling services, only to be told that the waiting list is months long. We've seen students forced to take time off from their studies due to mental health issues, only to be met with uncertainty and lack of support when they try to return.

The University of East Anglia's counselling programme is one of the best in the country, but even here, we've seen the cracks begin to show. Funding cuts and increased student numbers have led to a shortage of trained counsellors, leaving many students without the support they desperately need.

It's not just the universities that are struggling. Local mental health services are also feeling the strain. We've spoken to GPs and mental health professionals who are overwhelmed by the demand for their services, and are struggling to provide the level of care that patients deserve.

So, what does this mean for the electorate? It means that when you're making your decision at the ballot box, you need to look beyond the soundbites and empty promises. You need to ask the tough questions about how each party plans to support mental health, and what concrete actions they're willing to take.

As students and former students of the University of East Anglia's counselling programme, we're not asking for much. We're asking for a commitment to increasing funding for mental health services, to reducing waiting times for counselling, and to providing more support for students struggling with mental health issues.

We're not asking for a magic solution, but we are asking for a recognition that mental health is a serious issue that requires serious action. And we're asking the parties to take responsibility for the promises they're making, and to provide a clear plan for how they'll make a difference.

So, as you head to the polls, don't be fooled by the rhetoric. Look for the parties that are willing to put their money where their mouth is, and to take concrete action to support mental health. The future of our mental health depends on it.

Subsequent issues have also sold well, leading publisher Archant to decide to continue producing it on a rolling basis, though the company has made it clear it will pull the plug if interest wanes. The decision to continue publishing the New European comes as a welcome surprise to many Remain supporters who have been eager to see a dedicated voice for the pro-EU movement in the UK media landscape. The newspaper's success is attributed to its unique blend of news, analysis, and opinion pieces, which have resonated with readers across the country.

Archant, the publisher of the New European, has praised the newspaper's team for their hard work and dedication in producing a high-quality product that has captured the imagination of readers. "We are thrilled to announce that the New European will continue to be a part of the UK's media landscape," said a spokesperson for Archant. "The response to the newspaper has been overwhelming, and we are confident that it will continue to be a valuable platform for pro-EU voices."

The New European's editor, Matt Kelly, has also expressed his delight at the news, saying that the team is "buzzing" with excitement. "We knew that there was a huge appetite for a pro-EU newspaper, and it's fantastic to see that our readers have responded so positively," he said. "We're looking forward to continuing to produce a newspaper that reflects the views and values of the 48% who voted to remain in the EU."

The newspaper's success has also been praised by pro-EU campaigners, who see it as a vital tool in the fight to protect the UK's relationship with the EU. "The New European is a beacon of hope for those of us who believe that the UK should remain a part of the EU," said a spokesperson for the Remain campaign. "We are thrilled to see a newspaper that is dedicated to promoting a positive and constructive relationship between the UK and the EU."

Despite the positive news, the New European's publisher has made it clear that the newspaper's future is not guaranteed. "We will continue to monitor the newspaper's sales and circulation figures, and if interest begins to wane, we will not hesitate to make the difficult decision to pull the plug," said a spokesperson for Archant. "However, for now, we are confident that the New European will continue to be a valuable and important part of the UK's media landscape."

Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou has used his position as a major shareholder of African budget carrier Fastjet to demand that its directors be sacked. Haji-Ioannou, who has also been a longstanding critic of management at the EasyJet airline he founded, called a general meeting to immediately dismiss Fastjet's chief executive, Ed Winter, and remove another director, Krista Bates, from the main board, citing concerns over costs. Winter last month announced he would step down as chief executive, pending a successor being found, but a spokesman for Haji-Ioannou, who owns a 12% stake and helped set up the Tanzania-based airline, said it was time for a "clean break". Haji-Ioannou's demand for the removal of Fastjet's directors comes amid concerns over the airline's financial performance and management structure. In a statement, Haji-Ioannou's spokesman said that the company's current leadership has failed to address the airline's cost issues, which have led to significant losses in recent years.

"Fastjet's financial performance has been disappointing, and the current management has not been able to turn things around," the spokesman said. "Sir Stelios believes that a clean break is needed to bring in fresh leadership and a new approach to address the company's challenges."

Haji-Ioannou's criticism of Fastjet's management is not new. He has been a vocal critic of the airline's leadership for some time, and has previously called for changes to the company's strategy and management structure.

Fastjet's current chief executive, Ed Winter, announced last month that he would be stepping down from the role, pending the appointment of a successor. However, Haji-Ioannou's demand for his immediate removal suggests that the company's major shareholder is not satisfied with the pace of change.

The removal of Krista Bates, another director, from the main board is also seen as a significant move. Bates has been a member of Fastjet's board since 2015 and has played a key role in the airline's development.

Fastjet's shares fell sharply on the news, with the airline's stock price dropping by over 10% in early trading. The airline's financial performance has been under pressure in recent years, with losses reported in 2018 and 2019.

The company's financial struggles have been attributed to a range of factors, including increased competition in the African aviation market, rising fuel costs, and operational challenges.

Fastjet's board of directors has yet to comment on Haji-Ioannou's demands, but the company is expected to respond in the coming days. The situation is likely to be closely watched by investors and industry observers, who will be keen to see how the dispute is resolved and what impact it may have on the airline's future prospects.

Mark Zuckerberg has been asked to search for evidence that Russia-linked Facebook accounts were used to interfere in the EU referendum and the general election as part of a parliamentary inquiry into "fake news". Damian Collins, the chair of the digital, culture, media and sport committee, has written to the Facebook founder after suspicions that Russian "actors" used the platform to interfere in British politics. Facebook has 32 million users in Britain. Similar evidence on the 2016 US presidential election has already been supplied by Facebook to several US Senate committees, including the Senate intelligence committee, before a hearing with legal representatives from Facebook, Twitter and Google on 1 November in Washington DC. Facebook in the US disclosed last month that an influence operation that appeared to be based in Russia spent $100,000 (£75,000) on adverts to promote divisive political and social messages over a two-year period. Collins' letter to Zuckerberg requests that Facebook provide any evidence it may have of Russian-linked accounts being used to influence the EU referendum in 2016 and the general election in 2017. The inquiry is seeking to understand the extent to which social media platforms, including Facebook, were used to spread disinformation and propaganda during these elections.

The letter also asks Facebook to provide information on the number of users who may have been exposed to these Russian-backed advertisements, as well as any attempts made by the company to flag or remove these ads. Collins has given Facebook until November 20th to respond to his request.

The inquiry into "fake news" is a timely one, given the growing concerns about the impact of social media on democracy. The use of social media to spread disinformation and propaganda has been linked to several high-profile political events in recent years, including the 2016 US presidential election and the 2016 Brexit referendum.

Facebook has already faced criticism for its role in allowing Russian-linked accounts to spread disinformation on its platform. In September, the company announced that it had removed 32 pages and accounts that were linked to a Russian "troll farm" and were using Facebook to spread disinformation.

The company has also faced criticism for its slow response to the issue. In October, Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, admitted that the company had made mistakes in its handling of the issue and promised to do more to prevent the spread of disinformation on its platform.

The inquiry is likely to put pressure on Facebook to take more action to prevent the spread of disinformation on its platform. The company has already announced plans to increase its transparency around political advertising, but many critics argue that more needs to be done to prevent the spread of disinformation.

The inquiry is also likely to put pressure on other social media companies, including Twitter and Google, to take more action to prevent the spread of disinformation on their platforms. The three companies are scheduled to testify before the Senate intelligence committee on November 1st in Washington DC.

The inquiry is a significant development in the ongoing debate about the role of social media in democracy. As the use of social media becomes increasingly widespread, there is growing concern about the impact of disinformation and propaganda on political events. The inquiry is likely to shed more light on the issue and put pressure on social media companies to take more action to prevent the spread of disinformation.

About two weeks after a grisly shooting in a Pittsburgh suburb, Wendy Bell, a local news anchor for WTAE-TV, wrote a public Facebook post that focused in part on finding hope and offering kindness. But before the offering kindness part, she swerved into racial commentary that led to her being fired on Wednesday. She was responding to a shooting at a backyard party on March 9 in Wilkinsburg, Pa., that killed five people, including a pregnant woman. No one has been arrested, and the police have not yet publicly identified suspects. Yet in her Facebook post on March 21, which was later edited and eventually deleted, Ms. Bell played detective in a way that some felt relied on damaging stereotypes. The post, which was shared by Ms. Bell on her personal Facebook page, sparked widespread outrage and criticism from the community. In the post, Ms. Bell described the shooting as a "black on black" crime, using a term that many saw as perpetuating harmful stereotypes about African Americans. She also made assumptions about the victims and the perpetrators, without providing any concrete evidence or facts.

The post quickly went viral, with many people expressing their disgust and disappointment on social media. The Pittsburgh chapter of the National Association of Black Journalists issued a statement condemning Ms. Bell's comments, saying that they were "hurtful, inaccurate, and irresponsible."

WTAE-TV, the television station where Ms. Bell worked as a news anchor, initially stood by her, saying that she had the right to express her opinions on her personal social media page. However, as the backlash continued to grow, the station ultimately decided to fire Ms. Bell on Wednesday.

In a statement, the station said that Ms. Bell's comments "do not align with the values of WTAE-TV" and that they "do not condone or support harmful or divisive rhetoric." The statement also acknowledged that Ms. Bell's actions had caused harm to many people in the community.

The firing of Ms. Bell has sparked a wider conversation about the importance of responsible journalism and the need for news anchors and reporters to be mindful of the impact of their words. Many are calling for greater diversity and inclusion in the media, and for journalists to be more thoughtful and nuanced in their reporting.

The incident also highlights the need for news organizations to have clear policies and guidelines for their employees' social media use. While Ms. Bell's post was made on her personal page, it still reflected poorly on the station and its values.

As the investigation into the Wilkinsburg shooting continues, many are hoping for a swift and just resolution. In the meantime, the community is left to grapple with the aftermath of the tragedy and the harm caused by Ms. Bell's comments.

The library's collection of nearly one million items is a treasure trove of knowledge, featuring rare books, manuscripts, and other unique materials. The special collections include items such as ancient texts, rare books, and manuscripts, which are carefully preserved and maintained by the library's expert staff.

One of the most striking features of the Mansueto Library is its robotic book retrieval system. Patrons can browse the library's digital catalog and request books, which are then retrieved from the stacks by a robotic arm. The books are then delivered to the reader's location in the reading room, eliminating the need for lengthy searches through physical shelves.

The Joe and Rika Mansueto Library is not only a symbol of the University of Chicago's commitment to innovation and scholarship, but also a testament to the power of collaboration and generosity. The Mansueto family's donation has enabled the university to create a truly unique and forward-thinking library that will serve as a hub of intellectual activity for generations to come.

In conclusion, the Mansueto Library is a shining example of what can be achieved when cutting-edge technology meets a commitment to knowledge and learning. It is a place where students and scholars can come together to explore, discover, and create, and a testament to the University of Chicago's enduring commitment to excellence and innovation.

Ten years ago I studied for a masters in peace and development in Leeds. I used to rejoice as I walked through the municipal gardens near my home as we learned about the need for "capacity building" in the developing world. How grateful I was for all the local municipal provision that we lived with here: the parks, halls, toilets, youth centres, libraries. With central-government austerity policies (Cuts at catastrophic level, says Birmingham council chief, 13 December), they are now all vanishing, or hard-pressed local volunteers are struggling to deal with community-asset transfer, taking over the running and the management of such amenities, if they are not sold off to unaccountable private companies. As I reflect on my time in Leeds, I am struck by the stark contrast between the ideals we learned about in our peace and development program and the harsh reality that has unfolded over the past decade. The notion of "capacity building" in the developing world seemed like a noble pursuit, but it appears that the same principles are not being applied in our own backyard.

The municipal gardens that I once strolled through with such pride are now a distant memory, replaced by a landscape of uncertainty and decline. The very same parks, halls, toilets, youth centers, and libraries that we took for granted are disappearing, or struggling to stay afloat under the weight of austerity measures.

The consequences of these cuts are far-reaching and devastating. Not only do they erode the social fabric of our communities, but they also disproportionately affect the most vulnerable members of society. Children who once had access to safe and welcoming youth centers now find themselves with nowhere to turn. Elderly residents who relied on libraries for social connection and mental stimulation are left feeling isolated and forgotten.

The transfer of community assets to private companies has also raised concerns about accountability and transparency. Who is accountable for the maintenance and upkeep of these amenities? Who is responsible for ensuring that they are accessible to all members of the community? The lack of clear answers to these questions is a worrying trend that threatens to undermine the very fabric of our society.

As we look to the future, it is imperative that we re-examine our priorities and recommit to investing in our communities. We must recognize that the value of these amenities extends far beyond their monetary worth, and that they are essential to building strong, resilient, and connected communities.

In conclusion, the erosion of our municipal provision is a stark reminder of the need for a fundamental shift in our approach to governance and community development. We must work together to build a future that values the well-being of all members of society, and that recognizes the importance of community assets in fostering a sense of belonging and connection.

All chimpanzees will be designated as endangered under the Endangered Species Act, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced Friday. The move follows a petition filed in 2010 by Jane Goodall, The Humane Society of the United States and other groups to eliminate a longstanding distinction between the legal status of captive chimpanzees, which were previously listed as "threatened," and their wild counterparts, which have been deemed "endangered" for decades. According to the US Fish and Wildlife Service, the reclassification of chimpanzees is a significant step towards ensuring the long-term survival of the species. The agency cited declining populations, habitat loss, and poaching as major threats to the chimpanzees' well-being.

The decision comes after a thorough review of the species' status, which included input from scientists, conservationists, and the public. The Humane Society of the United States, which was one of the original petitioners, welcomed the news, stating that it was a "victory for animal welfare and conservation."

"We are thrilled that the US Fish and Wildlife Service has recognized the urgent need to protect all chimpanzees, regardless of their captivity status," said Kitty Block, CEO of the Humane Society of the United States. "This is a critical step towards ensuring the survival of these intelligent and social animals."

The reclassification is expected to have significant implications for the treatment and care of chimpanzees in captivity. Many organizations, including sanctuaries and research centers, will be required to meet stricter standards for the care and housing of their chimpanzee populations.

The US Fish and Wildlife Service will also work with international partners to address the global threats facing chimpanzees, including habitat destruction and poaching. The agency has committed to providing funding and support for conservation efforts, including habitat protection and research initiatives.

Dr. Jane Goodall, the renowned primatologist and conservationist, praised the decision, saying that it was a "major milestone" in the fight to protect chimpanzees. "This is a testament to the power of public advocacy and the importance of protecting our planet's precious biodiversity," she said.

The reclassification of chimpanzees is expected to take effect in the coming months, following a 30-day public comment period. The US Fish and Wildlife Service will also provide guidance and support to organizations and individuals affected by the change.

As the world's attention turns to the plight of the chimpanzees, conservationists are urging the public to take action. By supporting organizations working to protect chimpanzees and their habitats, individuals can make a difference in the fight to save these iconic animals.

Leishmaniasis parasites eat human flesh. Cordyceps fungi lead ants to suicide. Toxoplasma gondii eliminate a mouse's fear of cats. And a barnacle called Sacculina carcini castrates crabs, roots itself into their bodies and brains and transforms them into walking zombie slaves that care for the parasite's brood as if it were their own. Parasites are bad -- except when they're not. In recent years, the study of parasites has gained significant attention in the scientific community, shedding light on the complex relationships between these tiny creatures and their hosts. While many parasites are notorious for causing harm to their hosts, some have evolved to play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of ecosystems and even benefiting their hosts in unexpected ways.

One example of this is the relationship between the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii and its feline host. As mentioned earlier, Toxoplasma gondii has been known to eliminate a mouse's fear of cats, making them more susceptible to predation. However, this seemingly sinister behavior may actually be an adaptation to ensure the parasite's own survival. You see, Toxoplasma gondii needs to complete its life cycle by infecting a cat, where it can reproduce and produce oocysts that can then infect other hosts.

In this sense, the parasite's manipulation of the mouse's behavior can be seen as a clever strategy to increase its chances of transmission. This phenomenon has sparked interest in the field of evolutionary biology, with researchers seeking to understand the intricate mechanisms that drive the evolution of such complex relationships.

Another fascinating example of parasites playing a beneficial role is the relationship between the fungus Ophiocordyceps unilateralis and the carpenter ant Camponotus leonardi. The fungus infects the ant's body, eventually killing it, but not before causing the ant to climb to a high location and bite onto a leaf, allowing the fungus to produce spores that can spread to other ants. This peculiar behavior has led scientists to nickname the fungus the "zombie fungus" due to its ability to control the ant's actions.

Despite the seemingly sinister nature of this relationship, the fungus plays a crucial role in the ecosystem by breaking down organic matter and recycling nutrients. In fact, some researchers have suggested that the fungus may even be responsible for creating "ant cemeteries" that serve as nutrient-rich hotspots for other organisms.

These examples highlight the complex and often surprising ways in which parasites interact with their hosts. While some parasites are undoubtedly harmful, others have evolved to play a vital role in maintaining the balance of ecosystems and even benefiting their hosts in unexpected ways. As scientists continue to study these fascinating relationships, we may uncover even more surprising examples of parasites that are "bad" in the classical sense, but ultimately "good" for the greater good.

Two New York Times employees are suing the newspaper, citing "an environment rife with discrimination based on age, race, and gender". The class action lawsuit comes the same week that Curt Schilling accused ESPN of a culture of racism. Schilling was recently fired from his role as a commentator at the sports channel after making transphobic comments on Facebook. Racism in the media is often linked to a lack of diversity within the industry. And accusations that the workforce in US media doesn't represent the population are nothing new. In 1968, analyzing protests about the treatment of racial minorities, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders claimed that "the media report and write from the standpoint of a white man's world", adding "fewer than 5% of the people employed by the news business in editorial jobs in the United States today are Negroes." The lawsuit filed by the two New York Times employees is seeking compensation for alleged discriminatory practices within the company, including age, race, and gender-based biases. The complaint cites instances of unequal treatment, such as unequal pay, limited opportunities for advancement, and a lack of representation in senior leadership positions.

The lawsuit is not an isolated incident, as the media industry has long been criticized for its lack of diversity. Despite efforts to increase representation, the numbers remain stark. According to a 2020 report by the Media, Diversity, & Social Change Initiative at the University of Maryland, people of color make up only 12.4% of newsroom employees in the United States, while women hold just 37.6% of those positions.

The issue is not limited to the news industry, as the entertainment and sports sectors have also faced similar criticisms. The recent controversy surrounding Curt Schilling's comments on Facebook highlights the ongoing problem of racism in the media. Schilling's comments were widely condemned, and his subsequent firing from ESPN was seen as a necessary step to address the issue.

The lack of diversity in the media industry can have far-reaching consequences. When news is reported and presented through a narrow lens, it can perpetuate stereotypes and reinforce existing biases. This can lead to a lack of representation and understanding of marginalized communities, which can further exacerbate social and economic inequalities.

In recent years, there have been some efforts to increase diversity in the media industry. Many news organizations have implemented diversity and inclusion initiatives, such as training programs and mentorship schemes. Some companies have also made public commitments to increase representation and hiring practices.

However, more needs to be done to address the systemic issues that contribute to the lack of diversity in the media industry. The lawsuit filed by the two New York Times employees is a step in the right direction, and it highlights the need for greater accountability and transparency within the industry.

Ultimately, a more diverse and inclusive media industry is essential for creating a more equitable and just society. By addressing the systemic issues that contribute to the lack of representation, we can work towards a future where all voices are heard and valued.

One of the oldest breweries in Britain and its chairman have been fined almost £30,000 after they refused to hand over vital documents about its pension scheme. Samuel Smith Old Brewery, which was founded in Tadcaster in 1758, was asked to provide details of its pensions in 2015. The Pension Regulator (TPR) wanted to ensure the Yorkshire-based brewer and pub owner was earning enough money to support the final-salary pension schemes of more than 2,000 employees. However, the brewery owner, Humphrey Smith, 73, wrote back and dismissed the request as "tiresome". The Pension Regulator (TPR) took the matter to court, citing the brewery's failure to comply with its obligations under the Pensions Act 2008. The court subsequently ordered the brewery to provide the required documents, but Samuel Smith Old Brewery continued to resist, claiming that the request was "unnecessary" and "intrusive".

The TPR's investigation revealed that the brewery had failed to provide any information about its pension scheme, including details of its funding, investment strategy, and administration costs. This lack of transparency made it impossible for the regulator to assess the scheme's financial health and ensure that it was providing adequate benefits to its members.

In addition to the fine, the court also ordered Samuel Smith Old Brewery to pay the TPR's legal costs, which totaled over £10,000. The brewery's chairman, Humphrey Smith, was also ordered to pay a personal fine of £5,000 for his role in the breach.

The TPR's enforcement director, Nicola Parish, said that the case highlighted the importance of transparency and compliance in the pensions industry. "Employers have a legal duty to provide information about their pension schemes, and we will take action against those who fail to do so," she said.

The fine is the latest in a series of penalties imposed by the TPR on employers who have failed to comply with their pension obligations. In recent years, the regulator has taken action against a number of high-profile companies, including British Airways and the Co-operative Group, for similar breaches.

The case has also raised concerns about the impact of the fine on the brewery's employees, who are now left wondering about the future of their pension scheme. "We are deeply disappointed that the brewery has chosen to ignore its obligations to its employees," said a spokesperson for the TPR. "We will continue to work with the brewery to ensure that its pension scheme is properly funded and managed."

In response to the fine, Samuel Smith Old Brewery has issued a statement apologizing for any inconvenience caused and promising to work with the TPR to resolve the issue. However, the brewery has not commented on the specific allegations made against it or the reasons behind its failure to provide the required documents.

The case serves as a reminder of the importance of compliance with pension regulations and the consequences of failing to do so. Employers are reminded that they have a legal duty to provide information about their pension schemes and to ensure that they are properly funded and managed.

Shareholders appear to have blocked a pay rise for Alison Cooper, chief executive of Imperial Brands, in a move that may affect other FTSE 100 companies aiming to hike the bonuses of their bosses. The maker of Gauloises and John Player cigarettes issued an unexpected announcement to the stock exchange on Thursday to say it would not put its new pay policy to a vote as originally planned at the annual meeting on 1 February. The policy, which must be voted on every three years, would have had the effect of increasing Cooper's pay from £5.5m to a potential £8.5m a year from increased bonus opportunities. The move demonstrates that the company did not expect to win overwhelming support for the proposal from investors. The decision by ISS, the proxy voting agency which is influential with major US investors, to recommend a vote against the policy had signalled that a sizeable revolt was on the cards. The surprise move by Imperial Brands has sent a strong signal to other FTSE 100 companies that shareholders are increasingly scrutinizing executive pay packages. The company's decision to withdraw the new pay policy from the vote may also be a sign of a growing trend towards greater transparency and accountability in corporate governance.

Imperial Brands' proposal had been met with widespread criticism from institutional investors, who argued that the potential pay rise was excessive and did not align with the company's performance. The company's profits have been under pressure in recent years due to declining sales of its traditional tobacco products, and investors felt that the proposed pay hike was not justified.

The decision by ISS to recommend a vote against the policy was seen as a significant blow to Imperial Brands' plans. ISS is one of the most influential proxy voting agencies in the world, and its recommendations are closely followed by many institutional investors. The agency's decision to oppose the pay policy was likely influenced by concerns over the company's poor performance and the lack of transparency around its executive compensation practices.

The implications of Imperial Brands' decision are likely to be felt across the FTSE 100, where many companies are facing pressure from shareholders to reform their executive pay practices. In recent years, there have been several high-profile cases of excessive executive pay, which have led to increased scrutiny and criticism from investors and regulators.

The UK's Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has been urging companies to improve their executive pay practices, and has introduced new guidelines to help ensure that pay is aligned with performance. The FRC has also increased its scrutiny of company reports and accounts, and has taken enforcement action against companies that fail to comply with its guidelines.

In the wake of Imperial Brands' decision, other FTSE 100 companies may be forced to rethink their own executive pay policies. Companies such as British American Tobacco, Reckitt Benckiser, and Diageo, which have all faced criticism over their executive pay practices, may be forced to reconsider their approaches in the face of growing shareholder opposition.

Ultimately, the decision by Imperial Brands' shareholders to block the pay rise for Alison Cooper sends a clear message to companies and their executives: that transparency, accountability, and performance-based pay are essential for maintaining investor trust and confidence. As the debate over executive pay continues to rage, it remains to be seen whether other companies will follow Imperial Brands' lead and prioritize the interests of their shareholders over those of their executives.

The BBC appears to have lost sight of the purpose of its procedures (BBC defends censure of Naga Munchetty over Trump comments, theguardian.com, 27 September). The BBC guidelines are not laws. They are there to guide and are, therefore, open to interpretation. The recent controversy surrounding Naga Munchetty's comments on Donald Trump has sparked a heated debate about the role of the BBC's guidelines in shaping the tone and content of its programming. While the corporation has defended its decision to censure the presenter, many have argued that the guidelines are overly restrictive and stifle creativity and freedom of expression.

As the BBC's guidelines are not laws, they are indeed open to interpretation. However, this very flexibility can also be a double-edged sword. On one hand, it allows for nuance and adaptability in response to changing circumstances and audience expectations. On the other hand, it can also lead to inconsistencies and a lack of clarity, which can be detrimental to the corporation's reputation and the trust of its audience.

In the case of Munchetty's comments, the BBC's decision to censure her was seen by many as an overreaction. While the presenter's language was certainly provocative, it was also a reflection of the strong emotions and opinions that many people hold about the current political climate. By imposing its guidelines in a rigid and inflexible manner, the BBC risked stifling the very kind of debate and discussion that it purports to promote.

Moreover, the controversy has highlighted the need for the BBC to revisit its guidelines and ensure that they are more nuanced and context-sensitive. The corporation's guidelines should not be seen as a straitjacket that restricts creativity and freedom of expression, but rather as a framework that allows presenters and producers to make informed decisions about the content and tone of their programming.

Ultimately, the BBC's guidelines are only as effective as the corporation's willingness to engage with its audience and adapt to changing circumstances. By fostering a culture of openness, transparency, and creative freedom, the BBC can ensure that its programming remains relevant, engaging, and true to its values.

Hear the Sounds of Wind on Mars, Recorded by NASA's InSight Lander

That's the sound of winds blowing across NASA's InSight lander on Mars, the first sounds recorded from the red planet. It's all the more remarkable because InSight -- which landed last week -- does not have a microphone. Rather, an instrument designed for measuring the shaking of marsquakes picked up vibrations in the air -- sound waves, in other words. The recorded sounds, released by NASA on Monday, are a significant milestone in the agency's exploration of Mars. The InSight lander, short for Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transport, was specifically designed to study the internal structure of Mars and monitor the planet's seismic activity.

The sounds, which were recorded on April 5, are a series of gentle hums and rustling noises that are eerily similar to the sounds of wind blowing on Earth. According to NASA, the vibrations were detected by InSight's Seismic Experiment Package (SEIS), which is equipped with a highly sensitive seismometer designed to measure the slightest movements of the Martian surface.

"We were amazed when we heard the sounds," said Dr. Bruce Banerdt, the principal investigator for the InSight mission. "It's incredible that we're able to capture the sounds of wind on another planet, and it's a testament to the incredible technology that we've developed for this mission."

The recorded sounds are significant not only because they provide a new way of experiencing the Martian environment but also because they offer valuable insights into the planet's atmosphere. The vibrations detected by SEIS are thought to be caused by the movement of air molecules in the Martian atmosphere, which is much thinner than Earth's.

"This is a major breakthrough for our understanding of the Martian atmosphere," said Dr. Banerdt. "We've been studying the atmosphere of Mars for decades, but this is the first time we've been able to directly measure the movement of air molecules. It's a game-changer for our research."

The InSight lander is expected to continue studying the Martian atmosphere and internal structure for the next few years, providing valuable insights into the planet's history and potential for supporting life. The recorded sounds of wind on Mars are a reminder of the incredible discoveries that await us as we continue to explore our neighboring planet.

Within the 2.5 million acres of the Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve in central Alaska, wolves and other majestic animals are protected. But animals like wolves do not respect lines drawn on a map. And a recent study suggests that efforts to limit populations of these predators outside those borders is having negative effects on wolves living within the preserve. Researchers at the University of Alaska Fairbanks have been monitoring the movements of wolves within the Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve and surrounding areas. Their findings, published in the journal Ecology, reveal that efforts to control wolf populations outside the preserve's boundaries are having unintended consequences on the wolves living within the protected area.

According to the study, wolves are migrating from areas outside the preserve in search of food and mates, leading to an influx of new individuals into the protected area. However, this influx has resulted in increased competition for resources, such as prey and habitat, with the resident wolf population.

"The data suggests that the wolves within the preserve are experiencing reduced food availability and increased mortality rates due to the influx of new wolves," said Dr. Sarah Taylor, lead author of the study. "This is a concerning trend, as it can lead to a decline in the overall health and resilience of the wolf population within the preserve."

The researchers believe that the primary cause of this influx is the hunting and trapping of wolves outside the preserve's boundaries. While these activities are intended to control wolf populations and reduce conflicts with humans, they are having the opposite effect within the preserve.

"Wolves are highly mobile and can travel long distances in search of food and mates," explained Dr. Taylor. "By controlling their populations outside the preserve, we're inadvertently pushing them into the protected area, where they're competing with the resident population for resources."

The study's findings have significant implications for conservation efforts in the region. The researchers are calling for a more holistic approach to managing wolf populations, one that takes into account the interconnectedness of wolf populations across different areas.

"We need to consider the broader landscape and how our actions outside the preserve are impacting the wolves within it," said Dr. Taylor. "By working together with local communities, hunters, and trappers, we can develop more effective management strategies that balance human needs with wolf conservation."

The study's authors are hopeful that their findings will inform policy decisions and inspire a shift in the way wolf populations are managed in the region. As the debate around wolf conservation continues, one thing is clear: the fate of these majestic animals is closely tied to the actions of humans both within and outside the protected area.

The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) has been instrumental in driving this change, as it requires companies to give users greater control over their personal data and to allow them to easily transfer it to other services.

Facebook's data portability tool is expected to be rolled out to other European countries in the coming months, and the company has hinted that it may also be available in other regions in the future. The tool will allow users to download their Facebook photos and videos, as well as other data, and then upload them to rival services such as Google Photos, Apple Photos, or Microsoft OneDrive.

The move is seen as a response to criticism from regulators and privacy advocates that Facebook's dominance in the social media space gives it too much control over users' data. The company has faced numerous investigations and fines over its handling of user data, including a record-breaking $5 billion fine from the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) in July.

Facebook's rivals have long complained that the company's tight grip on user data makes it difficult for them to compete fairly. By making it easier for users to move their data to other services, Facebook is attempting to address these concerns and show that it is committed to giving users greater control over their data.

However, some experts have expressed skepticism about the move, suggesting that it may be too little, too late. "Facebook's data portability tool is a welcome step, but it's hard to see how it will fundamentally change the company's business model," said Dr. Emma Wilson, a digital privacy expert at the University of Oxford. "Facebook still has a lot of work to do to demonstrate its commitment to user privacy and data protection."

Despite these concerns, the move is seen as a significant step forward for users and could have far-reaching implications for the digital landscape. As the world becomes increasingly reliant on digital services, the need for greater transparency and control over personal data is becoming more pressing. Facebook's data portability tool is a recognition of this need, and it could pave the way for greater competition and innovation in the digital space.

The Guardian reported that the sandwich chain hoped to solve its looming recruitment crisis by offering 500 16- to 18-year-olds a week of unpaid work experience. The move has been hailed as a victory for the campaigners who spoke out against the plan.

The backlash was swift and intense, with many calling for a boycott of the company. Pret a Manger's chief executive, Clive Schlee, took to Twitter to respond to the criticism, saying that the company would pay all participants its hourly starting rate and provide free food as well.

"We understand that our initial proposal may have caused concern, and we apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused," Schlee tweeted. "We believe that our revised offer is a fair and reasonable compromise that will allow us to provide valuable work experience to young people while also respecting their time and effort."

The revised proposal has been met with widespread approval, with many praising Pret a Manger for listening to the concerns of critics and making a positive change. The company's decision to pay its employees is seen as a major victory for the campaign to protect teenagers from exploitation.

"This is a huge win for the campaign," said Sarah Jones. "Pret a Manger has shown that it is willing to listen to criticism and make changes to its policies. We hope that this decision will set a precedent for other companies to follow."

In the end, Pret a Manger's decision to pay its employees is a positive step forward, and one that sets a good example for other companies to follow. The controversy has also highlighted the need for greater transparency and accountability in the treatment of young people in the workforce.

The BBC should be turned into a mutual organisation and its board elected by licence fee payers, a pair of MPs has suggested. The broadcaster would benefit from more direct ownership by the people who pay for it, rather than the current system, which allows for too much government interference, Labour's Gareth Thomas and Tory MP Steve Baker said. "The BBC is a 'public service' broadcaster," Thomas and Baker wrote in a letter to the Times. "It operates under a royal charter, agreed between it and the government, is governed by a trust of the great and good appointed by ministers, and is funded by the licence fee payers. The two MPs, Gareth Thomas and Steve Baker, argue that the current system of governance and funding is flawed, and that a mutual organization would allow the BBC to operate more independently and make decisions that are truly in the best interests of its users.

Under a mutual organization, the BBC would be owned and controlled by its members, who would have a say in the direction of the organization and the way it is run. This would allow the BBC to be more responsive to the needs and concerns of its audience, and to make decisions that are driven by a desire to serve the public, rather than by government diktat.

Thomas and Baker point out that the current system of governance, which relies on a trust of "great and good" individuals appointed by the government, is undemocratic and lacks accountability. They argue that a mutual organization would be more transparent and accountable, and would allow the BBC to be more agile and responsive to changing circumstances.

The two MPs also argue that the current system of funding, which relies on the licence fee, is also flawed. They point out that the licence fee is regressive, and that it disproportionately affects the poor and vulnerable. They argue that a mutual organization would allow the BBC to find alternative sources of funding, and to be more sustainable in the long term.

Thomas and Baker's proposal has been welcomed by some, who see it as a way to increase transparency and accountability at the BBC. However, others have expressed concerns about the practicalities of implementing such a system, and about the potential risks of allowing the BBC to be controlled by a group of individuals rather than a government-appointed trust.

Regardless of the outcome, the debate highlights the ongoing challenges facing the BBC, and the need for the organization to find new and innovative ways to operate in a rapidly changing media landscape. As the BBC looks to the future, it will be interesting to see how it responds to the challenges and opportunities presented by the digital age, and how it will continue to serve the public interest in the years to come.

It was a problem that everyone knew was solvable, but one that had yet to be solved. Engineers, inventors and tinkerers had been working on "telemotion," the "televista," the "photo-telegraph," and the "tele-vision" in various forms, using well-known technologies and off-the-shelf equipment, since the early 20th century. Despite the numerous attempts, a practical and commercially viable solution for transmitting live, moving images over long distances remained elusive. However, the tide began to turn in the 1920s with the emergence of a new player in the field: John Logie Baird, a Scottish engineer with a passion for innovation.

Baird's breakthrough came in 1926, when he successfully demonstrated the first public transmission of live, moving images using a mechanical scanning system. His invention, known as the "televisor," used a spinning disk with a spiral of holes to capture and transmit images. Although the quality was still primitive, with a limited number of lines and a grainy, monochrome picture, Baird's achievement marked a significant milestone in the development of television.

In the years that followed, Baird continued to refine his design, and in 1928, he transmitted the first live, transatlantic television signal, beaming images from London to New York. This feat not only showcased the potential of television but also sparked a wave of interest and investment in the technology.

Meanwhile, another pioneer, Philo Farnsworth, a young American inventor, was working on an all-electronic television system. Farnsworth's design used a camera tube called the "image dissector" to capture images and a cathode ray tube (CRT) to display them. In 1927, Farnsworth successfully demonstrated his invention, transmitting live images for the first time.

The competition between Baird and Farnsworth drove innovation, and by the early 1930s, both engineers had developed more advanced systems. In 1936, the BBC launched the world's first regular high-definition television service, using Baird's mechanical system. However, Farnsworth's all-electronic system eventually became the standard, due in part to its greater reliability and flexibility.

The development of television was not without its challenges. The technology required significant infrastructure investments, including the construction of broadcasting towers, transmission equipment, and receiving devices. Additionally, the early systems were prone to interference, and the quality of the images was often poor.

Despite these hurdles, television continued to evolve, and by the 1940s, it had become a staple of popular culture. The first commercial television broadcasts began in the United States in the late 1940s, and by the 1950s, TV sets were a common fixture in millions of homes around the world.

In conclusion, the development of television was a long and arduous process, marked by numerous setbacks and challenges. However, the perseverance of pioneers like Baird and Farnsworth ultimately led to the creation of a technology that has had a profound impact on modern society. Today, television remains an integral part of our daily lives, providing entertainment, education, and news to people around the globe.

There is no cure for autism spectrum disorder, but there are medications that can help address associated symptoms like high energy levels and depression, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The agency has found that as many as a third of parents with an autistic child have tried treatments that most pediatricians do not recommend, and that up to 10 percent may be using potentially dangerous tactics. Concerns Over Unproven Autism Treatments Spark Warning from CDC

The CDC's findings suggest that up to 10 percent of parents with an autistic child may be using treatments that have not been scientifically proven or are even dangerous. These treatments can range from dietary supplements and herbal remedies to chelation therapy, which involves the use of chemicals to remove perceived toxins from the body.

Dr. Kathleen Etherton, a pediatrician and autism expert at the CDC, emphasized the importance of relying on evidence-based treatments for autism. "While we understand the desperation and frustration that many parents feel when dealing with the challenges of autism, it's crucial that we prioritize the safety and well-being of these children," she said.

The CDC's concerns are not unfounded. Chelation therapy, for example, has been linked to serious side effects, including kidney damage and heart problems. Similarly, some dietary supplements have been found to interact with prescription medications, potentially causing harm.

The agency is urging parents to consult with their pediatricians and other healthcare professionals before trying any new treatments for their autistic child. "We want to ensure that parents have access to accurate and reliable information about autism and its treatment," said Dr. Etherton. "We're working to raise awareness about the risks associated with unproven treatments and to promote evidence-based care for these children."

In addition to warning parents about the dangers of unproven treatments, the CDC is also working to improve access to effective treatments for autism. The agency has launched several initiatives aimed at increasing awareness and understanding of autism, as well as providing resources and support for families affected by the disorder.

For parents seeking guidance on evidence-based treatments for autism, the CDC recommends consulting with a qualified healthcare professional, such as a pediatrician or a developmental pediatrician. The agency also provides a wealth of information on its website, including fact sheets, videos, and resources for families.

Ultimately, the CDC's warning serves as a reminder of the importance of prioritizing the health and well-being of children with autism. By promoting evidence-based care and raising awareness about the risks associated with unproven treatments, the agency hopes to ensure that these children receive the best possible care and support.

Half a century ago, the Apollo astronauts left short-lived seismometers on the lunar surface. They found that the moon was alive and kicking. Some tremors deep below the surface likely were caused by Earth's gravitational pull. Others were vibrations from meteorite impacts. New Research Reveals Moon's Hidden Activity

Fifty years after the Apollo missions, scientists have made a groundbreaking discovery about the moon's internal dynamics. By analyzing the data collected by the seismometers left behind by the astronauts, researchers have uncovered a wealth of information about the moon's subsurface activity.

One of the most significant findings is that the moon is not as geologically dead as previously thought. The data suggests that the moon is still experiencing small-scale tectonic activity, which is likely caused by the cooling and contraction of the lunar interior over time. This process, known as "lunar contraction," is similar to what occurs on Earth, where the planet's interior cools and contracts, causing the crust to buckle and create mountains.

The Apollo seismometers, which were designed to measure moonquakes, detected numerous tremors and vibrations on the lunar surface. By analyzing these signals, scientists were able to pinpoint the source of the activity and determine that it was not just a result of meteorite impacts or Earth's gravitational pull. Instead, the data suggests that the moon's interior is still dynamic and active, with processes occurring deep beneath the surface.

"This is a major breakthrough in our understanding of the moon's internal dynamics," said Dr. Maria Zuber, a planetary scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. "The data collected by the Apollo seismometers has provided us with a unique window into the moon's subsurface, allowing us to study processes that would be impossible to observe on Earth."

The research has significant implications for our understanding of the moon's formation and evolution. It suggests that the moon may have experienced more significant geological activity in the past than previously thought, which could have played a role in shaping its surface features.

The findings also have practical applications for future lunar missions. By understanding the moon's internal dynamics, scientists can better plan and prepare for future missions, which could include establishing a sustainable human presence on the lunar surface.

As scientists continue to analyze the data collected by the Apollo seismometers, they are likely to uncover even more secrets about the moon's hidden activity. The discovery is a testament to the power of space exploration and the importance of continued investment in scientific research.

* Community land trusts: These non-profit organizations work to preserve affordable housing options by leasing land to homeowners at below-market rates.
* Co-living spaces: These shared living arrangements offer a more affordable and social alternative to traditional renting, often with amenities like shared kitchens and communal spaces.

Ultimately, the key to escaping rented accommodation is to explore all your options and consider what works best for your lifestyle and budget. Whether it's a houseboat, shared ownership, or something else entirely, there are many ways to achieve your goal of homeownership.

As the dollar has appreciated against other currencies, the value of foreign assets has decreased, making them less attractive to investors. Another factor is the divergent economic growth rates between the US and other developed economies. The US has been experiencing a period of strong growth, driven by low unemployment and fiscal stimulus, which has boosted consumer spending and business investment. In contrast, many other developed economies, such as the Eurozone and Japan, have been struggling with slower growth and deflationary pressures.

However, not all foreign markets are created equal. Some regions, such as Asia, have been experiencing rapid growth and have seen their stock markets perform relatively well. Despite the challenges facing foreign stocks, many analysts believe that the current environment presents opportunities for investors. With valuations at historic lows in many markets, investors may be able to pick up high-quality stocks at discounted prices. Additionally, the divergence in economic growth rates between the US and other developed economies is likely to continue, providing a tailwind for foreign stocks in the long term.

For investors looking to diversify their portfolios and take advantage of the opportunities in foreign markets, there are a number of strategies to consider. One approach is to focus on individual stocks rather than broad market indexes, which can provide more targeted exposure to specific countries or sectors. Another option is to consider investing in emerging markets, which have historically offered higher returns over the long term.

Ultimately, the key to success in foreign markets will depend on a combination of factors, including the investor's risk tolerance, investment horizon, and market selection. However, with the right approach and a dash of patience, investors may be able to find opportunities in foreign markets that can help them achieve their long-term financial goals.

If there was a tooth fairy in the Cretaceous, dinosaurs kept it busy. Unlike humans, which lose just one set of teeth over a lifetime, dinosaurs often lost tens or even hundreds of sets. Plant-eating dinosaurs had to chew lots of tough material to sustain their large bodies, causing them to frequently replace their teeth. New Research Reveals Tooth Fairy's Busy Schedule in the Cretaceous Era

The Cretaceous period, which spanned from 145 to 65 million years ago, was a time of immense diversity and complexity in the natural world. With the rise of flowering plants, modern mammals, and of course, the iconic dinosaurs, it's no surprise that the tooth fairy would have been kept busy. According to a recent study published in the journal PLOS ONE, the tooth fairy's workload was significantly higher in the Cretaceous era due to the unique dental habits of these prehistoric creatures.

As researchers from the University of California, Berkeley, discovered, many plant-eating dinosaurs had to chew through tough plant material to sustain their massive bodies. This constant wear and tear on their teeth led to frequent replacement, with some species losing tens or even hundreds of sets over their lifetime. In contrast, humans typically lose only one set of teeth throughout their entire lifetime.

The study's lead author, Dr. Emma Taylor, explained that the dental habits of dinosaurs were shaped by their diet and lifestyle. "Dinosaurs that ate tough, fibrous plants like ferns and cycads needed to constantly replace their teeth to maintain their ability to chew and digest their food," she said. "This meant that the tooth fairy had a constant stream of teeth to collect and replace, making it a very busy and important job."

The researchers used computer simulations and fossil records to estimate the number of teeth lost by different dinosaur species. They found that some species, such as the hadrosaurid (duck-billed) dinosaurs, lost up to 100 sets of teeth over their lifetime. This is significantly higher than the average human, who loses only 20-30 sets of teeth throughout their lifetime.

The study's findings have significant implications for our understanding of dinosaur biology and ecology. "By studying the dental habits of dinosaurs, we can gain insights into their diet, behavior, and evolution," said Dr. Taylor. "This research also highlights the importance of the tooth fairy's role in the Cretaceous ecosystem, and how it played a crucial part in the recycling of nutrients and energy."

While the tooth fairy may be a mythical figure in modern times, it's clear that its equivalent played a vital role in the ancient world. As we continue to learn more about the fascinating creatures that lived during the Cretaceous era, we are reminded of the importance of understanding the intricate relationships between species and their environments.
