Reclaiming mis-sold payment protection insurance can be a quick and easy process. There is no need to use a claims handling company that will rake off 30% of any compensation you are awarded. Can I claim mis-sold PPI? If you took out any kind of consumer loan, store card, credit card or mortgage in the 1990s or 2000s, you may have been mis-sold PPI. According to the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), millions of consumers in the UK were mis-sold Payment Protection Insurance (PPI) policies by banks and financial institutions. The insurance was designed to cover loan or credit card repayments in the event of illness, injury, or unemployment. However, many customers were not adequately informed about the policy's terms, conditions, and exclusions, leading to widespread mis-selling.

If you believe you were mis-sold PPI, you can reclaim the premiums you paid and any interest charged on those premiums. The good news is that the process of reclaiming PPI is relatively straightforward. You can start by gathering information about your loan or credit card, including the name of the lender, the date you took out the loan, and the amount you borrowed.

Next, you'll need to check your paperwork and statements to see if you were sold PPI. Look for any references to PPI or insurance policies, and note the dates and amounts of any premiums you paid. You can also contact your lender directly to ask if you were sold PPI and to request a copy of your policy documents.

Once you have this information, you can submit a claim to your lender. You can do this online, by phone, or in writing. Be prepared to provide detailed information about your loan and the PPI policy, including the dates and amounts of any premiums you paid.

The lender will then review your claim and respond with a decision. If your claim is successful, they will refund the premiums you paid and any interest charged on those premiums. You may also be eligible for compensation for any distress or inconvenience caused by the mis-selling.

It's worth noting that you don't need to use a claims handling company to reclaim PPI. These companies often charge a fee for their services, which can range from 20% to 30% of the compensation you receive. By submitting your claim directly to your lender, you can avoid these fees and keep the full amount of your compensation.

The deadline for making a PPI claim is August 29, 2019, so it's essential to act quickly if you think you may be eligible. The FCA has also introduced a "PPI complaints process" to help consumers make claims and resolve disputes with lenders.

In conclusion, reclaiming mis-sold PPI can be a quick and easy process, and you don't need to use a claims handling company to do so. By gathering your information, submitting a claim to your lender, and avoiding unnecessary fees, you can get the compensation you deserve and move on from this experience.

2004: Finn E. Kydland and Edward C. Prescott

Finn E. Kydland and Edward C. Prescott were awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Science in 2004 for their contributions to dynamic macroeconomics. Their work focused on the time consistency of economic policy and the driving forces behind business cycles. Kydland and Prescott's research challenged traditional economic theories, which assumed that policymakers could accurately predict and control economic outcomes. Instead, they demonstrated that policymakers often face uncertainty and that their decisions are influenced by the expectations of others.

Their work had significant implications for monetary policy, as it highlighted the importance of considering the potential consequences of policy decisions on future economic outcomes. This research also contributed to the development of new macroeconomic models, which have been widely used by policymakers and researchers around the world.

2002: Daniel Kahneman

Daniel Kahneman was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Science in 2002 for his work in integrating insights from psychological research into economic science. Kahneman's research focused on human judgment and decision making under uncertainty. He demonstrated that people's decisions are often influenced by biases and heuristics, rather than rational analysis of available information.

Kahneman's work had significant implications for the field of economics, as it challenged traditional assumptions about human behavior. His research showed that people are not always rational decision-makers, and that cognitive biases can have significant effects on economic outcomes. This work has been widely applied in fields such as finance, marketing, and public policy.

Vernon L. Smith was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Science in 2002 for his work in establishing laboratory experiments as a tool in empirical economic analysis. Smith's research focused on the study of alternative market mechanisms, including auctions and markets with multiple equilibria.

Smith's work had significant implications for the field of economics, as it provided new insights into the behavior of markets and the role of institutions in shaping economic outcomes. Facebook is launching a range of new tools in an effort to "put people in more control over their privacy" in the buildup to new EU regulations that tighten up data protection. The changes come after a troubling two weeks for the company, which is battling with the fallout of the Cambridge Analytica files. At least one of the new features, a unified privacy dashboard, was previously discussed by Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, back in January. The new tools, which will be rolled out over the coming weeks, aim to give users more transparency and control over how their personal data is used. The unified privacy dashboard will provide a single place for users to view and manage their privacy settings, making it easier for them to understand how their data is being used and to make informed decisions about how it is shared.

Another new feature is a "data use" policy that will clearly outline how Facebook uses and shares user data. This policy will be presented to users in a clear and concise manner, making it easier for them to understand how their data is being used and to make informed decisions about how it is shared.

Facebook is also introducing a new "access token" feature, which will allow users to revoke access to their data from third-party apps. This feature will give users more control over who has access to their data and will help to prevent unauthorized access.

In addition to these new features, Facebook is also increasing the number of data protection officers it has in place. These officers will be responsible for ensuring that Facebook's data protection policies are being followed and for investigating any data breaches that may occur.

The changes come as Facebook faces increased scrutiny over its handling of user data. The company has faced criticism over its role in allowing Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm, to harvest the data of millions of Facebook users without their consent. Facebook has also faced criticism over its handling of data breaches, including a recent breach that affected 50 million users.

"We recognize that we have more work to do to earn back the trust of our users," said two Facebook executives in a blog post announcing the changes. "We are committed to transparency and accountability, and we will continue to work to ensure that our users have the control and protection they deserve."

The changes are part of Facebook's efforts to comply with the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into effect on May 25. The GDPR requires companies to provide users with more transparency and control over how their data is used, and to obtain explicit consent from users before collecting and processing their personal data.

Facebook's efforts to comply with the GDPR are not without controversy. The company has faced criticism over its handling of user data and its efforts to comply with the regulation. Some have argued that Facebook's efforts to comply with the GDPR are insufficient and that the company is not doing enough to protect user data.

Despite the controversy, Facebook's efforts to comply with the GDPR are a step in the right direction. As the company continues to work to earn back the trust of its users, these changes are an important step towards rebuilding that trust.

They may have had more than a sneaking suspicion that it was the case, but now working mothers have the data to back it up: they are indeed more stressed than other people – 18% more, in fact. And that figure rises to 40% for those with two children, according to a major study that analysed 11 key indicators of chronic stress levels. Professor Tarani Chandola, of Manchester University, and Dr Cara Booker, Professor Meena Kumari and Professor Michaela Benzeval, of the Institute for Social and Economic Research at Essex University, examined biological data taken by nurses from 6,025 participants in the UK Household Longitudinal Survey, the largest survey of its kind in the world. The study, published in the journal Social Science and Medicine, found that working mothers experienced higher levels of stress across multiple indicators, including cortisol levels, blood pressure, and self-reported stress levels. The researchers controlled for factors such as age, education, and socioeconomic status to ensure that the results were not skewed by demographic differences.

One of the most striking findings was the significant difference in cortisol levels between working mothers and other groups. Cortisol is a hormone released in response to stress, and higher levels can have negative effects on physical and mental health. The study found that working mothers had an average cortisol level 18% higher than the general population, while those with two children had a whopping 40% higher level.

"This study highlights the often-overlooked impact of childcare responsibilities on women's health and wellbeing," said Professor Tarani Chandola, lead author of the study. "Working mothers are shouldering a significant burden, and it's essential that policymakers and employers take notice."

The researchers also found that working mothers were more likely to experience sleep disturbances, fatigue, and depression than other groups. These findings are consistent with previous studies that have shown the negative effects of work-life conflict on mental and physical health.

So, what can be done to alleviate the stress experienced by working mothers? The study's authors suggest that employers could play a crucial role by offering flexible working arrangements, such as telecommuting or flexible hours, to help working mothers better manage their responsibilities.

"Employers can make a real difference by recognizing the challenges faced by working mothers and providing support," said Dr. Cara Booker, co-author of the study. "This could include offering childcare support, such as on-site childcare or childcare vouchers, or simply being more understanding of the needs of working mothers."

The study's findings have significant implications for policymakers, who are grappling with issues such as childcare support, parental leave, and equal pay. As the study's authors note, the stress experienced by working mothers is not just a personal issue, but also has broader social and economic implications.

"This study highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the challenges faced by working mothers," said Professor Meena Kumari, co-author of the study. "We need to move beyond simplistic solutions and develop policies that truly support working mothers and their families."

In the meantime, working mothers can take heart in knowing that they are not alone in their struggles. The study's findings are a powerful reminder that the challenges they face are real, and that it's time for society to take notice and take action.
